Date:  Thu, 01 Jan 2009 11:53:08 -0000
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  Happy New Year to all - and our last image of 2008
Dear comet friends,

because my flagship ST10XME is out of order till now, my wife Wen and
I took this image of C/2006 W3 (Christensen) with our Canon EOS350D
out of desperation on New Year's Eve.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2006w3_20081231.htm

Also a snapshot camera is able to enjoy our comet hearts.

A HAPPY NEW YEAR to everybody here and thank you for your great images.

Bernhard and Wen

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/

Subject:  color images of comets
Hi to all,
challenging the polar yesterday's cold, have done
some comets color: I find interesting development
of the 29P that after yet another outburst it shows a
S "structure" to already seened in previous events

http://comete.uai.it/144p/144P_090103.jpg
http://comete.uai.it/2006of2/C2006OF2_090103.jpg
http://comete.uai.it/29p/29P_090103.jpg

best regards
Rolando Ligustri

Date:  Mon, 05 Jan 2009 22:07:17 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Comet C/2007 N3 Lulin orbit edge-on
Hello folks,

I wonder if anyone else has noticed that we are observing comet C/2007 N3
Lulin "edge-on".
With incredible fortune, the orbital inclination of the comet is 178
degrees. i.e. virtually in the same orbital plane as the Earth.
This means from Earth's perspective, we will observe the comet edge-on
throughout the apparition!
The effect of this is to enhance the surface brightness of the comet and its
dust tail.
Take the deep sky example of an edge-on galaxy being more readily observable
than one that is face-on.

Recently posted images are displaying the sharp sunward pointing dust tail
(antitail) in PA 100, along with the ion tail at PA 280.
The dust tail should remain at approximately PA 100 to 110 and appear as a
sharply defined "needle-like" appendage.
Since most of the dust particles are released in the comets wake, the dust
tail will rapidly lengthen after Lulin's flyby of the Earth on Feb 24,
length uncertain but perhaps a few degrees long.
The ion tail however will appear considerably shortened, since it will be
pointing directly away from the Sun when the comet is located at opposition
on Feb 26.

Looking forward to observing this unusual comet.

Cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo 

Date:  Mon, 05 Jan 2009 23:06:02 +0100
From:  walcom77 
Subject:  C/2007 N3 (Lulin) - 02 January 2009
Hi All

Here you can see our most recent image of comet Lulin (02 January
2009) taken remotely from from Mayhill (NM) through a 0.25 f/3.4
reflector + CCD:

http://tinyurl.com/a7egcl

Ernesto Guido, Giovanni Sostero and Paul Camilleri
http://remanzacco.blogspot.com/ 

Date:  Mon, 05 Jan 2009 15:56:56 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2007 N3 (Lulin) - 02 January 2009
Question:
It appears to me that you have a third extension of the coma for this comet:
the broader one extending to the east (PA 100) left in your image (in the direction of the tear drop)

the very thin one extending opposite to the above PA 280

a third extension to the west PA 270

>From Michael Mattiazzo's description in a previous post, the broader extension at PA 100 in the solar direction (left) is the dust tail and the narrow extension at PA 280 (right) is the ion tail.

Could that third extension be a jet?

This is a very sharp image of this comet. My compliments to your group!!

Also thank you Michael Mattiazzo.

________________________________

Date:  Tue, 06 Jan 2009 19:45:35 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2007 N3 (Lulin) - 02 January 2009
Hello all,

Here's an image from Lulin observatory itself.

http://yeiht.y234.cn/wordpress/

Check out the 3 ion tail filaments at PA 280 (to the left of the comet).
and the dust tail spike (antitail) to the right of the comet at PA 100.

cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo

Date:  Tue, 06 Jan 2009 14:31:06 -0000
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  Re: C/2007 N3 (Lulin) - 02 January 2009
Hello Michael, Charles and all,

Quanzhi's comet on Lulin Observatory's last image shows the following
details:
image 2009-01-02 UT ~21:30 anti-tail: 9'40" in PA 100°, three ion
tails: 12'11" in PA 292°, 10'55" in PA 286°, 5'32" in PA279°

Thanks a lot for the image to Ye Quanzhi who discovered the comet at
the Lulin Observatory. I turned the picture 180° and measured the
tails. And thanks to Michael for his analyses.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3.htm

clear skies

Bernhard

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/

Date:  Wed, 07 Jan 2009 08:07:51 -0000
From:  rotorzilla_jp 
Subject:  Comet P/2008 X4 Christensen

I was able to image Comet 210P P/2008 X4 Christensen on Jan 5th 2009
0650 GMT, just as the sun was coming up. The comet was right at the
horizon limit of the scope. I was only able to take a wide field
image, as the High Mag image train is having a filter wheel issue that
needs hands on attention.

http://heliospheric-labs.com/gallery/d/17907-1/20090105_015230_7659-2.jpg

Thanks

Tony Farkas
Okinawa, Japan

From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  Jan 8th image of 2007 N3 Lulin
As the UK has now descended into subzero temperatures and
dense fog I resorted to GRAS New Mexico to remotely image
2007 N3 Lulin a few hours ago.....
http://uk.geocities.com/martin.mobberley@btinternet.com/2007n3_20090108_mpm.jpg

Date:  Thu, 08 Jan 2009 20:42:10 -0000
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  C/2006 W3 (Christensen) again, January, 08 2009  UT 17:09
Hi comet friends,

from my location at latitude 50°, the comet has a good position for
taking images in the evening hours.

Inspite of a Moon phase of 91%, the image is worth to post here:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2006w3_20090108.htm

Try also the full size image:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2006w3_20090108_orig.htm

We have here -10°C (14°F), but very good seeing and clear skies.

CS

Bernhard

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/ 

Date:  Fri, 09 Jan 2009 11:05:30 +0100

Hi comet friends,

Date:  Sat, 10 Jan 2009 04:03:11 -0000
From:  Quanzhi Ye 
Subject:  Comet Lulin on Jan. 5 -- near-nucleis jets shown
Dear all,

I admitted I haven't been here for long -- so now I'm back with some
nice images.

I have updated three carefully-processed images to my blog, you can
check them out at http://yeiht.y234.cn/wordpress/?p=1245.

At least 9 jets in the near-nucleis area can be seen, as well as
some structure of the ion-tail.

Enjoy!

Quanzhi

Date:  Wed, 14 Jan 2009 13:19:46 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  144P / C/2006 OF2 - 2009/01/14
Hello
Could be just less moonlight but this comet 144P was bright and
seemed to want to grow a tail. OF2 was showing less tail. Images are
with the IR/UV blocking filters. Clouds were around but don't think
were a problem at the time of these images
Thanks, Mike H.

144p

Here are my images of Comet 144P/Kushida from the night of January
14, 2009 taken from mag 5/6 skies.

http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3330/3198885042_61621dda69_b.jpg

http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3355/3198039065_e311ee114d_b.jpg

http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3259/3198038755_32778bbc09_o.jpg

Photo details:
Baton Rouge, Louisiana
Mississippi River Levee
Canon EF 50mm f/1.8 II Camera Lens
at f/3.5
Piggybacked on C8
Canon XTi
12 X 120 second exposures (24 min. total)
ISO 400
7:52-8:16 PM CST
0:52-1:16 UT

James 

Date:  Fri, 16 Jan 2009 00:35:44 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Need help from the imagers----Please!
Hello.
For all my years imaging I have used CcdSoftV5 or CCDops to combine
my fits or sbig imagesdone with astro cameras. There have never been
problems combining in the ADD, AVERAGE or MEDIAN formats with these
programs. Now I have a DSLR which only allows JPG or RAW images. I
have PS2 and PS3 but don't know how to combine 2 or more images. I can
copy and paste in PS but there must be more to combining to acheve the
total of both. Are there any software programs that will combine JPG
and or RAW images that are not cost crazy? Or perhaps someone can
point me to a PS solution I can learn.
I really thought that at some point in my long live (57yrs) I would
have enough shi# to just coast for a while. Now I need some more shi#
so if anyone can give me some ideas of software or how to in PS JPG
images I would appreciate it. I love this hobby but I am becoming very
CHEAP!
Thanks and have a good day!
Mike H. 

Date:  Fri, 16 Jan 2009 01:32:05 +0000
From:  Stéphane Garro 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Need help from the imagers----Please!
Hello Mike,

Le 16 janv. 09, à 00:35, tricks46 a écrit :

> total of both. Are there any software programs that will combine JPG
> and or RAW images that are not cost crazy? Or perhaps someone can
> point me to a PS solution I can learn.

Did you try IRIS software by Chistian BUIL ?
See here (in english):
http://www.astrosurf.com/buil/us/iris/iris.htm

It is freeware and seems very powerful for dealing with DSLR
astronomical Raw images.

Stephane

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Fri, 16 Jan 2009 02:29:08 -0000
From:  jcham21 
Subject:  Re: Need help from the imagers----Please!
Another very good and free program is deepskystacker:
http://deepskystacker.free.fr/english/index.html

And make sure to always shoot in RAW for astrophotos. That way no
information is wasted.

James

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2009 11:05:58 -0000
From:  Rob 
Subject:  Comet C/2007 Q3 (Siding Spring)
I have uploaded a widefield image of this comet to my files. Haven't
really seen much around of this one yet, but it is slowly brightening
in southern skies at the moment.

Apologies for the poor quality - my gear is pretty crude, hand-guiding
on EQ1 mount, and I had particular difficulty this night with the
guiding (hence elongated stars). At this scale, it appears tucked in
against mag 10.1 field star TYC8097-51-1. I hope someone with good
gear can get a better shot at it!

http://tinyurl.com/9ml6sz

Cheers -

Rob 

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2009 11:09:07 -0000
From:  Rob 
Subject:  Re: Comet C/2007 Q3 (Siding Spring)

Cheers -

Rob

Date:  Mon, 19 Jan 2009 10:07:55 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: 29P January 16, 2009 0407UT
For comets, I can currently reach around mag 17 with a lot of stacked frames and binning the ccd imaging chip.

I am using a 12 inch Meade LX200 scope, SBIG ST8-XME CCD camera with photometric filters on a filter wheel, (usually just the red filter), plus a focal reducer and extension tube, and an AO-7 unit for guiding. I get effectively a focal length of around 1445 mm as calculated with Astrometrica which is a focal ratio of f/4.7

           Pixel Size: 1.28" x 1.28", Field of View: 32.7' x 21.8'
The FWHM of the stars in my images are typically 3 to 4 arc sec.

Yes I have tried to recover several comets over recent months.

With my limitations, I just stick with astrometry of comets and NEOs.

Apparently, one must be at a higher drier elevation than I am at to get any deeper  or cough up lots of kilobucks for a larger scope. I am retired, so that's not going to happen for me.

________________________________
From: James R. Schofer
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, January 18, 2009 10:47:30 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: 29P January 16, 2009 0407UT

your limiting magnitude with the set up ? Do you ever attempt recovery
objects. Regards James

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/michael%20jaeger/210P20090119lrgbnet.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/members/web/index.htmlfiles

schmidtcamera2500

the night.

Date:  Sun, 25 Jan 2009 20:02:55 -0000
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet 29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann January 23, 2009  0635UT
Comet 29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann
jet emanating from coma at PA 200

January 23, 2009 0635UT

http://flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/3225533439/

Telescope: 12 inch (0.3m) Meade 200LX-GPS at f/4.7
CCD: SBIG ST-8XME self guided with + AO-7 using CCDOPS
Filter: Red
Exposure: 17 x 238 seconds
Image orientation: North up East left
sub frames stacked with Astrometrica
cropped to center 

Date:  Sun, 25 Jan 2009 22:49:54 -0000
From:  emartincz 
Subject:  144P Jan25 with Hyades
Hi all.

I captured 144P Kushida this evening. I took two fields and gave them
together, so Aldebaran and Hyades are on the left and comet on the right.

In small frame is comet 100% crop.

4 x 2min left + 7 x 2 min right frame
Canon 300D + Sigma 4/135 mm, ISO 800
25.1.2009, 17:30-18:30 UT
Jablonec n.N, Czech Republic

http://udalosti.astronomy.cz/obraz/foto/comet/144p-hyady_20090125_1024px.jpg

Martin Gembec

Date:  Mon, 26 Jan 2009 20:56:03 -0000
From:  iferrinv 
Subject:  Do you have images of Comet C/2002 CE10?
Hi all:
Seiichi Yoshida in his web site says that comet C/2002 CE10
exhibited an unusual straight tail from a nucleus without any
coma. Since this is not common, I would like to see some
images to confirm this extrange type of activity. Please write
to me to ferrin@ula.ve. Thanks.

Ignacio Ferrin
Center for Fundamental Physics,
University of the Andes,
Merida, Venezuela

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ 

Date:  Mon, 26 Jan 2009 22:31:41 +0100
From:  Jose Pablo Navarro Pina 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Do you have images of Comet C/2002 CE10?
Hi Ignacio ,

This comet is dec. = -48 º for my observatory is very low and not observable actually , the distance geocentric is 12 u.a. , and the last list of MPC of comets observables not included the comet C/2002 CE 10 , this comet is very interesting for observing and investigated the phase coefficients is 0.03 and have period of 30 yrs. , this is possible new type of comets of system solar .

Best Regards , Jose Pablo Navarro .

----- Original Message -----
From: iferrinv
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, January 26, 2009 9:56 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Do you have images of Comet C/2002 CE10?

Hi all:
Seiichi Yoshida in his web site says that comet C/2002 CE10
exhibited an unusual straight tail from a nucleus without any
coma. Since this is not common, I would like to see some
images to confirm this extrange type of activity. Please write
to me to ferrin@ula.ve. Thanks.

Ignacio Ferrin
Center for Fundamental Physics,
University of the Andes,
Merida, Venezuela

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:  C/2006OF2(Broughton)
Hi,

on the 25th I made an image of Broughton and was surprised that the
tail is fairly long (my FOV is about 40' with my set up, so the comets
tail is approx. 20' long). Data and link to image is on my homepage:

http://members.aon.at/fandrosc/page_8_2.html

Mike

Date:  Fri, 30 Jan 2009 02:03:22 +1100
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  P/2008 Y3 - McNaught
I've just posted an image of this 18th mag comet. Even though it is faint, and the comet
is at a distance of 4 AU, there is a well defined tail extending for 35" in PA 330deg

The image is a stack of 10 x 2min exposures. Image size is 3 arc min square. Image is
located at:

http://tinyurl.com/an5tzf

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

Date:  Sat, 31 Jan 2009 19:19:25 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  OBS - Vis and image of C/2007N3 (Lulin)
Hi all,

I visually observed and imaged C/2007 N3 (Lulin) this morning (2009 January 30.62 UT) - and also imaged it with my 41cm (16") Newtonian @ f5.2, modified 350D, 13 x 2 minute exposures @ 800 ISO. The tail and antitail are clearly evident. The FOV is about 40' x 25'.

C/2007 N3 (Lulin)
2009 January 30.62 UT: m1 = 6.7, Dia.= 6'.0, Tail = 20' in PA 285*, DC = 5, 8cm f5 Refract (13x)...John Drummond, (Gisborne, New Zealand) [Can easily see Lulin with 10x50 binoculars. A tail was seen extending for 20' in a PA of 285*. 40˚ alt in the E. Stellar LM = 6.3 near comet (naked eye), dark, rural sky].

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet_2007n3-lulin-41cm@f5,2-350d_13x2min@800asa-090130-ave-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/aosk5d

Cheers

John Drummond
Possum Observatory (IAU Code: E94)
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 177° 53', S 38° 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Date:  Sun, 01 Feb 2009 18:44:21 -0000
From:  Dale 
Subject:  Recent Comet images
Thanks for adding me to your group.

The set up used: NS11 gps, Hyperstar (3rd gen), XSVF H9C (OSC)
The images in my Album (Tucson Nights) were taken on the evening and
morning of 28/29 Jan 2009. All images were taken unguided at 60 to 90
sec exposures, combining 20 to 30 images using one star align,Combined
(Med) and applying DDP.
Processing was accomplished using: MaxIm DL, and PS2
Images: Broughton C/2006 of 2, Kushida 144p, AND Lulin C2007 N3

Has anyone written up their process for developing a comet image or can
direct me to one that has proven to work.

I have used: www.newastro.com/newastro/tutorials/comet_technique.asp

Thanks
Dale

Date:  Wed, 04 Feb 2009 20:09:00 +0100
From:  dfischer@astro.uni-bonn.de
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Feb 4th image of 2007N3 (Lulin)
These wonderful - independent - image sets raise the question:
Is there a central depository for high-quality ion tail images?
There have been special calls for observations (in connection
with the Ulysses mission) at times, but these were limited in
time and scope. The need for a central archive of comet tail
images - like we have for comet visual data at ICQ, for example,
or for variable stars at AAVSO - could yield invaluable scientific
results.

For example, 20 years ago (in those dark pre-web times) comet
Okazaki-Levy-Rudenko "suffered" some wonderful disconnection
events, and by pure chance high-quality images (yes, real photos)
reached me from several astrophotographers working independently
in the same hour. Many tail features could be measured and speeds
and - surprisingly high - accelerations calculated. (The results
were published in the Proceedings of the first Meeting of
European Planetary and Cometary Observers in 1992.)

Daniel 

Date:  Wed, 04 Feb 2009 20:34:49 +0100

Date:  Thu, 05 Feb 2009 19:04:47 +1100
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Feb 4th image of 2007N3 (Lulin)
Gidday Martin,
The anim sequence is very interesting.
I wonder if your saw my post in Comet-ML in the photo section under the stereo images folder.

C/2007 N3 Dynamics 20090101
As seen in SECCHI/STEREO images a dynamic Tail, each image frame is 40 mins cadence
By: algwat
File Name: c2007N3-lulin dynamic-20090101-H1b.gif
Posted: Jan 7, 2009
Resolution: 300x300
Size: 3,122KB

This shows a similar tail dynamic with Lulin. Not as high resolution.
As Lulin crossed the STEREO HI1b FOV I counted about three similar events,. All moved in different directions, so I assume solar wind interactions.
It would good to see if an extended sequence of frames could be capture across a single night. There is likely to be more dynamics to see.

Kind regards,
Alan Watson

Http://cometal.bigblog.com.au/index.do

Irmtraut [j.j.mueller@onlinehome.de]
OBS J.J. M\"uller
MEA J.J. M\"uller
TEL 0.31-m f/4.8 reflector + CCD
ACK MPCReport file updated 2009.02.05 13:31:00
AC2 j.j.mueller@onlinehome.de
NET USNO-B1.0
0074P C2009 01 30.00792 09 32 37.32 +22 48 15.2 17.7
N A21
0074P C2009 01 30.00942 09 32 37.25 +22 48 15.5 17.9
N A21
0074P C2009 01 30.01093 09 32 37.14 +22 48 15.8 17.8
N A21
0074P C2009 01 30.01391 09 32 37.07 +22 48 16.3 17.8
N A21
0074P C2009 01 30.01766 09 32 36.92 +22 48 17.5 17.6
N A21
0074P C2009 01 30.01917 09 32 36.79 +22 48 17.9 17.6
N A21
----- end -----

Clear skies

Josef Mueller A21 

Date:  Thu, 05 Feb 2009 14:24:01 -0000
From:  martin316928 
Subject:  Re: Feb 4th image of 2007N3 (Lulin)
Hi Alan,

Thanks for your message....very interesting. I get the
comets-ml summaries but missed that. Thanks to all for
their messages re. yesterday's images...I am having
trouble keeping up with all the e-mails on the Feb 4th
tail disconnection!
Observadores Cometas via Mark Kidger/Montse Campàs have
uploaded the full frame animation to their website at

http://www.observadores-cometas.com/cometas/2007n3/imagenes/C2007N3-
090204-mpm.gif

Regards,
Martin

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Alan Watson"
wrote:
>
> Gidday Martin,
> The anim sequence is very interesting.
> I wonder if your saw my post in Comet-ML in the photo section
under the stereo images folder.
>
> C/2007 N3 Dynamics 20090101
> As seen in SECCHI/STEREO images a dynamic Tail, each image frame
is 40 mins cadence
> By: algwat
> File Name: c2007N3-lulin dynamic-20090101-H1b.gif
> Posted: Jan 7, 2009
> Resolution: 300x300
> Size: 3,122KB
>
> This shows a similar tail dynamic with Lulin. Not as high
resolution.
> As Lulin crossed the STEREO HI1b FOV I counted about three similar
events,. All moved in different directions, so I assume solar wind
interactions.
> It would good to see if an extended sequence of frames could be
capture across a single night. There is likely to be more dynamics
to see.
>
> Kind regards,
> Alan Watson

GRAS New Mexico, has been uploaded. Some

is brightening the western edge of the frame....

Date:  Fri, 06 Feb 2009 13:22:08 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  Feb 6th image of 2007N3 (Lulin)
My 11th shot of comet Lulin, imaged remotely via
GRAS New Mexico, has been uploaded. Considerable
stray light from mag 2 Zuben Elgenubi is brightening the
frame and the Moon was only a degree below the horizon.

Temporary image location:
http://uk.geocities.com/martin.mobberley@btinternet.com/2007n3_20090206_mpm.jpg

Comets page:
http://uk.geocities.com/martinmobberley/Comets.html

Regards, Martin

Date:  Sat, 07 Feb 2009 18:06:39 -0000
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  four comets of this week: 29p, 65p, 116p, c2006of2
Hi comet friends,

here is an update of my homepage:

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/29p.htm

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/65p.htm

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/116p.htm

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2006of2.htm

clear skies

Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/ 

Date:  Sun, 08 Feb 2009 11:12:54 -0000
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  C/2008 T2 (Cardinal) February 2 and 3
Hi comet friends,

the comet is still very weak and lies 3 mag under its expectation line.
At Feb.,3 it shows a small coma and a faint tail in PA128°.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2008t2_20090202.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2008t2_20090203.htm

Each site contains both images and detailled descriptions of
astrometry and photometry.

clear skies

Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/ 

Date:  Sun, 08 Feb 2009 18:16:23 -0000
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  C/2007 N3 (Lulin) at February,3 2009
Hi friends,

here is my b/w image on the size of 24' x 16', 3 min. exp.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20090203.htm

Astrometry and photometry included.

CS

Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/

Date:  Wed, 11 Feb 2009 13:46:53 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  AW: [Comet-Images] animacion del lulin
Hello Gustavo,

your wonderful animation with tail and anti-tail animated me to produce also
a small movie of my 10 frames from February,3.

Unfortunately the comet was only 23° above horizon. End of February I can
observe the comet at an altitude of 38°. Thats much better.

10 x 180 sec. reduced to a 1 second .gif animation.

SCT 12 f-7 and ST10XME

2009-02-03 UT 05:10 to 05:41

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20090203_animation.h
tm

Saludos and clear skies after the Full Moon phase

Bernhard

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project

Date:  Sun, 15 Feb 2009 20:48:01 -0000
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  211P/Hill and 29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann at Febrary, 14  2009
Hi cometgazers,

here are two of 9 images of the last night:

The very weak comet 211P/Hill (18.6 mag) was passed by the asteroid
Eucryphia (17.3 mag). Both objects had a speed of 0.55"/min.
211P/Hill moved in PA 35.2°, Eucryphia in PA 63.3°.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/211p_20090214.htm

The second image is showing the very special shape of the central
condensation of comet 29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann:

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/29p_20090214.htm

Clear skies

Bernhard Häusler, Maidbronn
MPC B82

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/

February 19, 2009
2:24-4:00 AM CST

Autofocus on Saturn
Piggybacked on Celestron C8 Fork Mount
Canon XTi
15 X 240 sec. exposures
ISO 800

able to take this half hour session.

stacked on the stars a nice distant galaxy was captured (I.D.?) on
lower right of frame.

Date:  Fri, 20 Feb 2009 15:02:02 -0000
From:  "R.Ferrando" 
Subject:  Animation C/2007 N3 (20090220)
Hello
In the following ones you are linked he can see the animation of comet
They are files AVI compressed RAR, to see it better it is necessary to
put the reproducer in continuous so that the animation repeats.

Reduced animation size (8 Mb):
http://www.pla-de-arguines.com/C2007N3-20090220-REDU.rar

Recommended
Animation to real size (24Mb):
http://www.pla-de-arguines.com/C2007N3-20090220.rar

Greetings
Rafa Ferrando

Date:  Sat, 21 Feb 2009 17:08:02 +1300
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  Comet Lulin with a 300mm Mamiya lens
Hi all,

here's an image of Comet Lulin (C/2007N3) taken last night - about 12 hours ago (2009 February 20.62 UT).

The image was taken with a Canon 350D DSLR camera (modified) and 300mm Mamiya lens @ f5.6. I used 13 x 5 minute exposures @ 1600 ISO -

http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/comet2007n3-lulin-300mm_mamiya@f5,6-350d-13x5mins@1600asa-090220-drummond-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/cakzq6

The comet is readily seen with the naked eye as a faint, fuzzy patch of about mag 5 not far from Corvus...

Cheers and thanks.

John Drummond
Possum Observatory (IAU Code: E94)
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 177° 53', S 38° 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Date:  Sun, 22 Feb 2009 15:37:55 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  c/2007 N3 Lulin observations and image Feb 21, 2009
Hello all,

Here are my visual observations of comet C/2007 N3 Lulin during February 09.
Tycho 2 VT magnitude comparison stars were used.
Latest images can also be seen at:

http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/lulin.htm

Please note: my usual southern comets homepage website is currently offline
for some unknown reason.

ICQ recent comet mags format
2009
Feb. 21.54, 5.0, (M. Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, naked eye);
Feb. 21.54, 4.9, 18' (M. Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, 10x50
binoculars);
Feb. 20.52, 5.0, 20' (M. Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, 10x50
binoculars);
Feb. 04.67, 6.1, 9' (M. Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, 10x50 binoculars);
Feb. 03.73, 6.2, 8' (M. Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, 10x50 binoculars);
Feb. 02.73, 6.3, 7' (M. Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, 10x50 binoculars);
Feb. 01.73, 6.3, 7' (M. Mattiazzo, Castlemaine, Victoria, 10x50 binoculars);

Morris format
2009 Feb 21.54 UT: m1=5.0, DC=5...naked eye...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)
[in-in method]
2009 Feb 21.54 UT: m1=4.9, Dia.=18', DC=5...10x50mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)
[comparisons Pi Vir, 7 Vir, Eta Vir. Sidgewick method. Through 25x100mm
binoculars, a starlike central condensation is visible within a large
circular coma. The dust tail is traceable out to 1/2 degree in PA 112. In a
CCD image taken at the same time, the dust tail is 1.7 degrees long in PA
112 and a faint ion tail is 0.5 degrees in PA 296.]
2009 Feb 20.52 UT: m1=5.0, Dia.=20', DC=5...10x50mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)
2009 Feb 04.67 UT: m1=6.1, Dia.=9', DC=5...10x50mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)
2009 Feb 03.73 UT: m1=6.2, Dia.=8', DC=5...10x50mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)
2009 Feb 02.73 UT: m1=6.3, Dia.=7', DC=5...10x50mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)
2009 Feb 01.73 UT: m1=6.3, Dia.=7', DC=5...10x50mm B...Michael Mattiazzo
(Castlemaine, Victoria)

Cheers
Michael

Date:  Sun, 22 Feb 2009 12:12:11 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/20007 N3 Hi-Res image and animation  (21 feb 2009)
Dear All,

I'm pleased to share this Hi-Res image of comet Lulin:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/c2007n3_lulin_20feb09.jpg

Details are below in the image.

As you can see, there is an eviden, structured 'T' feature
in the inner coma.

On the same night I enjoyed looking at the comet motion,
doing this animation:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/c2007n3_20feb09.gif

Happy comet,
Gianluca

work.

Date:  Sun, 22 Feb 2009 13:45:26 +0000
From:  Gustavo Muler 
Subject:  Re[2]: [Comet-Images] 3 hours animation Lulin 507mm.
Estimado Clay and colegues, thank you very much.
here is another animation of the same pictures, this time is a Track
and Stack of 10 images, the right time of exposures is 70 sec, (700
secs.)
I am triing to process the picture but in the track and stack I loose
a lot of information of ionic tail of his oun movements. maybe will be
interesting to process it ten by ten ???
best regards, here the animation...

http://astrosurf.com/nazaret/images/cometas/C2007N3/C2007N3-09021-J47a.gif

gracias !

> Hi Group!
> This morning the comets AntiTail was severely distorted as shown here.

Hi Efrain, in your photo
the component in the lower left is the ion tail
the component in the top right is the dust tail
or anti tail.

best regards
Rolando

Date:  Mon, 23 Feb 2009 06:20:09 -0600
From:  "Dr. D. T. Durig" 
Subject:  Animations of Comet Lulin from 2/23 UT (and some earlier ones)
I have put my animations of Comet Lulin from this morning (2-23) and 2/17
etc on a special comet observation page found here:

http://arthur.sewanee.edu/obsv/view_c.php

You can see lots of rays coming from the coma and a plume from the tail well
ahead of the coma.

Dr. D. T. Durig

Director of the Cordell-Lorenz Observatory

OBS COD 850

Professor of Physics

Professor of Chemistry

The University of the South

Sewanee, TN

931-598-1570 office

931-598-1458 Observatory

recent observations at http://arthur.sewanee.edu/obsv/view.php

ddurig@sewanee.edu

Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Lulin color
Hi Phil,

whoa that's a great image! One of the best that I have seen.

How do you get this fast moving comet to be stationary against the background stars? I presume it's a layering process in Photoshop. I'd love to know how...

Cheers

John Drummond
NZ

http://www.astrosurf.com/nazaret/ 

Date:  Mon, 23 Feb 2009 19:27:02 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Comet Lulin color
Here is a link to one method.
http://tinyurl.com/cfomro
Hope this link works
Mike H.

Date:  Mon, 23 Feb 2009 20:33:19 -0000
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  discovery of a new object close to comet 116P/Wild at Febr. 15 and Febr. 19
Hi comet friends,

while taking images of comets, there is a good chance to detect new
other objects. Here is the story:

At an image of Febr.,15 of comet 116P/Wild I found three asteroids,
two of them are already known, one of them was a suspected new object.

At February, 19 I found the new object on another of my images of
116P/Wild by chance, because the object is escorting the comet since a
couple of days!

First detection:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/116p_20090215.htm

Confirmation image:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/116p_20090219.htm

The MPC confirmed the new object at February, 23 2009 with the number
K09C45D

Thanks to Gustavo Muler from the Canarian Islands for his great help!

Clear skies

Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/ 

Date:  Mon, 23 Feb 2009 13:54:10 -0800
From:  Efrain Morales 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] discovery of a new object close to comet 116P/Wild at Febr. 15 and Febr. 19
Hi Bernhard, Congratulations. That is great news capturing this new asteroid, A very fine effort indeed my friend and a great cooperative assistance from Gustavo. Welldone to both and Clear Skies.
Efrain Morales Rivera  ( jaicoa-observatory.com )

Btw Nice Iamge also.

--- On Mon, 2/23/09, Bernhard Häusler wrote:

From: Bernhard Häusler
Subject: [Comet-Images] discovery of a new object close to comet 116P/Wild at Febr. 15 and Febr. 19
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Monday, February 23, 2009, 4:33 PM

Hi comet friends,

while taking images of comets, there is a good chance to detect new
other objects. Here is the story:

At an image of Febr.,15 of comet 116P/Wild I found three asteroids,
two of them are already known, one of them was a suspected new object.

At February, 19 I found the new object on another of my images of
116P/Wild by chance, because the object is escorting the comet since a
couple of days!

First detection:
http://www.amicatio n.de/Bernhards_ Comet_Project/ 116p_20090215. htm

Confirmation image:
http://www.amicatio n.de/Bernhards_ Comet_Project/ 116p_20090219. htm

The MPC confirmed the new object at February, 23 2009 with the number
K09C45D

Thanks to Gustavo Muler from the Canarian Islands for his great help!

Clear skies

Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82

http://www.amicatio n.de/Bernhards_ Comet_Project/

Date:  Tue, 24 Feb 2009 15:32:08 +0100
From:  Jose Pablo Navarro Pina 
Subject:  C/2007 N3 LULIN + Filter Swan Band
Hi all ,

Image of C/2007 N3 LULIN + Filter Swan Band , is a narrow band-pass filter (25nm), isolates the 501nm OIII line and both C2 lines at 511nm and 514nm for this comet :

http://webs.ono.com/jpab

Regards , J.P.Navarro Pina
Observatorio Astronomico Vega del Thader
Murcia , Spain , MPC-J70

Date:  Tue, 24 Feb 2009 16:20:28 +0100
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] C/2007 N3 LULIN + Filter Swan Band
> Image of C/2007 N3 LULIN + Filter Swan Band , is a narrow band-pass filter (25nm), isolates the 501nm OIII line and both C2 lines at 511nm and 514nm for this comet

The only "Swan Band" filter commercially available I'm aware of, it that of LUMICON (that, incidentally, fits your description). As stated here:
http://tinyurl.com/bv27ds
this filter is "Not intended for photography". This means that if you are using it with a CCD, you are also getting the dust continuum in the red wing of the spectra, where the LUMICON "Swan band filter" is no more "narrow band-pass". So, what you actually recorded in your image is a mixture of emission lines + dust continuum (the first part dust tail is well visible). If you really want to isolate the C2 emission lines, you must subtract from your image another one, that shows solely the dust continuum.

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero 

Date:  Tue, 24 Feb 2009 15:55:46 -0000

Martin

Date:  Tue, 24 Feb 2009 17:20:43 +0100
From:  Jose Pablo Navarro Pina 
Subject:  Re: Re:[Comet-Images] C/2007 N3 LULIN + Filter Swan Band
¿¿¿¿....???? > The only "Swan Band" filter commercially available I'm aware of, it that of LUMICON (that, incidentally, fits your description). As stated here:
http://tinyurl.com/bv27ds
this filter is "Not intended for photography". This means that if you are using it with a CCD, you are also getting the dust continuum in the red wing of the spectra, where the LUMICON "Swan band filter" is no more "narrow band-pass". So, what you actually recorded in your image is a mixture of emission lines + dust continuum (the first part dust tail is well visible). If you really want to isolate the C2 emission lines, you must subtract from your image another one, that shows solely the dust continuum.<

I do not share his opinion, the exact description and more details and information and use of this filter is here :

http://www.lumicon.com/telescope-accessories.php?iid=LF3075&cid=17&in=Filter+Comet+2in&hn=

I user personal processing method for isolate the C2 emission lines in my images ccd publisher .

Regards , J.P.Navarro .
----- Original Message -----
From: gvnn64@libero.it
To: Comet-Images
Sent: Tuesday, February 24, 2009 4:20 PM

> Image of C/2007 N3 LULIN + Filter Swan Band , is a narrow band-pass filter (25nm), isolates the 501nm OIII line and both C2 lines at 511nm and 514nm for this comet

The only "Swan Band" filter commercially available I'm aware of, it that of LUMICON (that, incidentally, fits your description). As stated here:
http://tinyurl.com/bv27ds
this filter is "Not intended for photography". This means that if you are using it with a CCD, you are also getting the dust continuum in the red wing of the spectra, where the LUMICON "Swan band filter" is no more "narrow band-pass". So, what you actually recorded in your image is a mixture of emission lines + dust continuum (the first part dust tail is well visible). If you really want to isolate the C2 emission lines, you must subtract from your image another one, that shows solely the dust continuum.

Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero

80MM F/5.2 ST8XME
COMET
http://astrosurf.com/nazaret/images/cometas/C2007N3/C2007-090224-J47COMET1.avi.gif

STARS
http://astrosurf.com/nazaret/images/cometas/C2007N3/C2007-090224-J47COMET1.avi.gif
--
Saludos, Gustavo Muler.

Observatorio Nazaret, MPC J47

http://www.astrosurf.com/nazaret/

Date:  Wed, 25 Feb 2009 18:41:44 +0100

Bernhard

B82

Von: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] Im
Auftrag von Efrain Morales
Gesendet: Montag, 23. Februar 2009 22:54 in Rimpar
An: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Cc: jaicoa52@yahoo.com
Betreff: Re: [Comet-Images] discovery of a new object close to comet
116P/Wild at Febr. 15 and Febr. 19

Hi Bernhard, Congratulations. That is great news capturing this new
asteroid, A very fine effort indeed my friend and a great cooperative
assistance from Gustavo. Welldone to both and Clear Skies.
Efrain Morales Rivera ( jaicoa-observatory.com )

Btw Nice Iamge also.

--- On Mon, 2/23/09, Bernhard Häusler > wrote:

From: Bernhard Häusler >
Subject: [Comet-Images] discovery of a new object close to comet 116P/Wild
at Febr. 15 and Febr. 19
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Monday, February 23, 2009, 4:33 PM

Hi comet friends,

while taking images of comets, there is a good chance to detect new
other objects. Here is the story:

At an image of Febr.,15 of comet 116P/Wild I found three asteroids,
two of them are already known, one of them was a suspected new object.

At February, 19 I found the new object on another of my images of
116P/Wild by chance, because the object is escorting the comet since a
couple of days!

First detection:
http://www.amicatio n.de/Bernhards_ Comet_Project/ 116p_20090215. htm

Confirmation image:
http://www.amicatio n.de/Bernhards_ Comet_Project/ 116p_20090219. htm

The MPC confirmed the new object at February, 23 2009 with the number
K09C45D

Thanks to Gustavo Muler from the Canarian Islands for his great help!

Clear skies

Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82

http://www.amicatio n.de/Bernhards_ Comet_Project/

Date:  Thu, 26 Feb 2009 21:19:36 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  comet Lulin images Feb 25th 2009
Hello all,

Latest images of Comet 2007 N3 Lulin can be seen at:

http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/lulin.htm

Please note: I am unable to update my usual southern comets homepage website
for some unknown reason.

2009 Feb 25.50UT.
>From Left to Right:

40x10 second exposures, Starlight Express MX7c imager + C11 at f/3.3.
Stacked on the comets nucleus. Larson Sekania filter processing to bring out
detail in the dust jets emanating from the nucleus.

15x1 minute exposure. 135mm Hanimex lens at f8, MX7c CCD imager. FOV 2.5
degrees wide. south at top. The dust tail stretches 2 degrees.

5x2 minute exposures, Canon 300D digital camera, 300mm zoom lens.

2x3minute exposures, Canon 300D digital camera.90mm zoom lens, cropped
image. ISO 800. Note Saturn in the field at far right. FOV 10 degrees wide.

Cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo 

Date:  Thu, 26 Feb 2009 15:01:13 +0100
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2007 N3 - 26 Feb. 09 - Hi-Res image
Dear All,

I'm pleased to share this interesting image of the comet,
showing its very inner coma:

http://virtualtelescope.bellatrixobservatory.org/c2007n3_26feb09_ls.jpg

30, 2-min exposures were averaged before to perform a
rotational gradient. Some possible features are visible.

Image scale is 0.62"/pixel and seeing was 2". South is up,
West on the left.

C14@f/8.7 + SBIG ST8-XME (NABG) + Paramount ME

Best,
Gianluca

Date:  Fri, 27 Feb 2009 01:28:04 -0000
From:  Chris Thuemen 
Subject:  Comet Lulin- The Movie ,  Feb. 24,2009.  Pembroke, Ontario
Hello!
This is my first contribution to the group. Since learning of Comet
Lulin and having reviewed the course that it was to follow, I
realized that this comet would provide a unique opportunity to
record a comets movement through the night sky. Having taken
multiple images of both Comet Linear VZ13/2007(July 2007) and Comet
8/P Tuttle(Jan. 2008) I noticed that a comets movement could easily
be recorded.

So back in January when I had first imaged Lulin in the breaking
dawn of Jan.9th, I made plans to record a series of images to
assemble into a movie. My best opportunity, in fact my only
opportunity came Feb. 24th. As I set up my gear to get polar
aligned, what was a clear sky, began to slowly cloud over. Very
light clouds, but dense enough to block out Polaris in the setting
twilight, After about twenty minutes of scanning the north sky,
Polaris became visible, a ghost of its normal self. With alignment
complete, all I could do was wait for 11:00 p.m. to arrive which
brought Leo up over the trees of my rear yard.

Several visits to the window throughout the evening, indicated that
Murphy was alive and well. In the midst of a late night episode of
NCIS, I thought I would venture one final look before I went out and
stripped down the gear. I couldn't believe my eyes. Somehow a
complete constellation Leo, could be seen through a slight haze of
high cirrus type cloud. The surrounding clouds did not appear to be
moving so I said, This Is It!!

Within 5 minutes I began what I hoped would be a 40 image series,
shot with my Canon 300D at prime focus, 800 ISO and 60 second
exposures. Seeing was not great, tranparency about 2 out of 5, but
the comet was visible through my 50mm finder.I was using my Orion
120x1000 refractor on an EQ5 mount. The first couple of images to
set focus looked promising so I kept on shooting. There was to be
very little time for any fine tuning. As if by design, I had just
finished my 40th frame and the hole in the clouds closed up. It took
all of about 5 minutes. I was elated that I was to get what I did.
The forcast for the next few days is cloud and more cloud.

The movie contains 40 images that have had no processing other than
reducing file size. I have yet to determine the distance covered in
that one hour, but as you will see from the movie clip, it was
conciderable.

I hope you enjoy the clip as much as I had fun putting it together.
I will have to give credit to a couple of fellow amateur observing
friends, Rob Lavoie and Stephan Lalonde from Ottawa, for putting
together the clip.

You will find it in the files section, "Comet Lulin The Movie".

Cheers, Chris.

Date:  Sun, 01 Mar 2009 16:18:45 -0000
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  images of C/2006 OF2 and C/2006 W3
Hi comet friends,

here are some more comet images of February:

C/2006 OF2 (Broughton) is still a nice object in the evening skies.
C/2006 W3 (Christensen) was passing the Sun's longitude towards the
morning sky with a nice tail up to direction North.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2006of2_20090214.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2006of2_20090217.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2006of2_20090218.htm

Date:  Fri, 06 Mar 2009 16:50:47 -0500

Subject:  Comet Lulin / M44 Flyby
Hi, Group, I finally escaped winter's icy grip in North Central Ohio by
fleeing to Charlotte, North Carolina. I was able to witness and photograph
the Comet Lulin M44 Flyby.

I've posted images on my Flicker site here



Hope you enjoy my humble images.

Astronomically, John

http://www.onealwebsite.com

Date:  Sat, 07 Mar 2009 19:25:28 -0000
From:  Chris Thuemen 
Subject:  Re: Comet Lulin / M44 Flyby
Hi John!

Great images. We were clouded up here in Canada, as we are so often, that I missed this event. Thanks for sharing. One question...you have the one image where you stacked the stars and the comet separately. Are you able to share the process you used. I have a few similar images of Comet Lulin that I would like to process that way. This comet is moving so fast that stacking images would seem impossible to freeze both stars and the comet. I look forward to reply.

Thanks!!

Cheers, Chris.

Date:  Mon, 09 Mar 2009 20:41:01 -0000
From:  nmarmet 
Subject:  Comet C/2007 N3 Lulin - 2009 Partial Eclipse
- Comet Lulin C/2007 N3 crossed the shadow of the Earth. It should be possible to see the small variation in intensity in photos taken on Feb. 26, 2009, near 9:00UTC.If anyone has photos of this penumbral eclipse, please let me know!

see
"http://www.marmet.org/louis/lulin2009/index.html"

Date:  Tue, 10 Mar 2009 14:41:18 -0000
From:  peterbus 
Subject:  Re: Comet C/2007 N3 Lulin - 2009 Partial Eclipse
Dear nmarmet,

Interesting thought, however a hypothetical observer on the comet with properly eye protected sun filters is seeing the passage of Earth's dark silhouette across the bright disk of the Sun. The dark silhouette has at that moment a diameter of about 42 arc seconds. This is smaller than Venus's diameter (58 arc seconds) at the transit on June 8 in 2004.
Unfortunate for you, no detectable variation in intensity of C/2007 N3 is possible.

Sincerely,

Peter Bus
Groningen
The Netherlands

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "nmarmet" wrote:
>
> - Comet Lulin C/2007 N3 crossed the shadow of the Earth. It should be possible to see the small variation in intensity in photos taken on Feb. 26, 2009, near 9:00UTC.If anyone has photos of this penumbral eclipse, please let me know!
>
> see
> "http://www.marmet.org/louis/lulin2009/index.html"
>

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Tue, 10 Mar 2009 17:36:42 -0000
From:  nmarmet 
Subject:  Re: Comet C/2007 N3 Lulin - 2009 Partial Eclipse
Dear Peter,
I agree with you the variation of intensity is very small and it might be impossible to measure with standard simple instruments. What I had in mind is to compare the average intensity of the comet before the passage and also during the passage. The change would be invisible to the naked eye. The expected variation is 1/1000. This is very small but if I had some picture taken that night it would be worth the time to do some computations.

Thanks,
Nicolas Marmet

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "peterbus" wrote:
>

The dark silhouette has at that moment a diameter of about 42 arc seconds. This is smaller than Venus's diameter (58 arc seconds) at the transit on June 8 in 2004.

Date:  Tue, 10 Mar 2009 19:42:55 -0000
From:  peterbus 
Subject:  Re: Comet C/2007 N3 Lulin - 2009 Partial Eclipse
Dear Nicolas,

When Earth occulted the Sun on February 26 2009 as seen from comet Lulin this gives a magnitude drop of about -0.001 magnitudes.
In my opinion this is not traceable.
The theoretical drop in magnitude due the variation in r and delta in your given period of occultation is much greater; about 0.05 magnitudes.

Sincerely,

Peter Bus
Groningen
The Netherlands

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "nmarmet" wrote:
>
> Dear Peter,
> I agree with you the variation of intensity is very small and it might be impossible to measure with standard simple instruments. What I had in mind is to compare the average intensity of the comet before the passage and also during the passage. The change would be invisible to the naked eye. The expected variation is 1/1000. This is very small but if I had some picture taken that night it would be worth the time to do some computations.
>
> Thanks,
> Nicolas Marmet
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "peterbus" wrote:
> >
> > Dear nmarmet,
> >
> > Interesting thought, however a hypothetical observer on the comet with properly eye protected sun filters is seeing the passage of Earth's dark silhouette across the bright disk of the Sun. The dark silhouette has at that moment a diameter of about 42 arc seconds. This is smaller than Venus's diameter (58 arc seconds) at the transit on June 8 in 2004.
> > Unfortunate for you, no detectable variation in intensity of C/2007 N3 is possible.
> >
> > Sincerely,
> >
> > Peter Bus
> > Groningen
> > The Netherlands
> >
> > --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "nmarmet" wrote:
> > >
> > > - Comet Lulin C/2007 N3 crossed the shadow of the Earth. It should be possible to see the small variation in intensity in photos taken on Feb. 26, 2009, near 9:00UTC.If anyone has photos of this penumbral eclipse, please let me know!
> > >
> > > see
> > > "http://www.marmet.org/louis/lulin2009/index.html"
> > >
> >
> 

Date:  Wed, 11 Mar 2009 01:59:38 -0000
From:  nmarmet 
Subject:  Re: Comet C/2007 N3 Lulin - 2009 Partial Eclipse
Peter,
I did some computation for the drop in magnitude. It came out smaller that 0.05 but bigger than what I am trying to observe. Over that period of time the difference for the apparent visual magnitude was -0.004. This is 4 times bigger than what I am trying to measure. I guess I will have to wait for a comete closer to the earth!

The brightness formula of a comet is:
m1 = m0 + 5log(delta) + 2.5nlog(r)
The beginning of the eclipse occurred at ~7:55UTC and ended at ~9:40UTC. The r and delta for that same period of time went from r=1.4094, delta=0.4192 to r=1.4099, delta=0.4197.

Start
m1 = 6.5 + 5log(0.4192) + 2.5 x 4 x log(1.4094)
m1 = 6.5 + 5 x (-0.37758) + 2.5 x 4 x 0.149034
m1 = 6.10244

End
m1 = 6.5 + 5log(0.4197) + 2.5nlog(1.4099)
m1 = 6.5 + 5 x (-.37706) + 2.5 x 4 x 0.149188
m1 = 6.10658

The difference for the apparent visual magnitude is 0.004.
The Variation in Brightness is:
V = 2.512^(-0.004) = 0.996
Thanks,

Nicolas

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "peterbus" wrote:
>
> Dear Nicolas,
>
> When Earth occulted the Sun on February 26 2009 as seen from comet Lulin this gives a magnitude drop of about -0.001 magnitudes.
> In my opinion this is not traceable.
> The theoretical drop in magnitude due the variation in r and delta in your given period of occultation is much greater; about 0.05 magnitudes.
>
> Sincerely,
>
> Peter Bus
> Groningen
> The Netherlands
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "nmarmet" wrote:
> >
> > Dear Peter,
> > I agree with you the variation of intensity is very small and it might be impossible to measure with standard simple instruments. What I had in mind is to compare the average intensity of the comet before the passage and also during the passage. The change would be invisible to the naked eye. The expected variation is 1/1000. This is very small but if I had some picture taken that night it would be worth the time to do some computations.
> >
> > Thanks,
> > Nicolas Marmet
> >
> > --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "peterbus" wrote:
> > >
> > > Dear nmarmet,
> > >
> > > Interesting thought, however a hypothetical observer on the comet with properly eye protected sun filters is seeing the passage of Earth's dark silhouette across the bright disk of the Sun. The dark silhouette has at that moment a diameter of about 42 arc seconds. This is smaller than Venus's diameter (58 arc seconds) at the transit on June 8 in 2004.
> > > Unfortunate for you, no detectable variation in intensity of C/2007 N3 is possible.
> > >
> > > Sincerely,
> > >
> > > Peter Bus
> > > Groningen
> > > The Netherlands
> > >
> > > --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "nmarmet" wrote:
> > > >
> > > > - Comet Lulin C/2007 N3 crossed the shadow of the Earth. It should be possible to see the small variation in intensity in photos taken on Feb. 26, 2009, near 9:00UTC.If anyone has photos of this penumbral eclipse, please let me know!
> > > >
> > > > see
> > > > "http://www.marmet.org/louis/lulin2009/index.html"
> > > >
> > >
> >
>

Date:  Sun, 15 Mar 2009 13:53:51 -0000
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  New images are uploaded on my website: C/2008 T2, C/2007 N3, C/3006 OF2, 33P
Hello comet friends,

here are some new images of three weak and one prominent comet.

33P was definitely ending its outburst last week:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/33p_20090314.htm

Comet Lulin showed a thin gaseous tail going along with its dust streams at March 13:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20090313.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20090311.htm

The brightness of comet Broughton is striking decreased at March 13:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2006of2_20090313.htm

Comet C/2008 T2 (Cardinal) is still sleeping on around 15 mag.
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2008t2_20090314.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2008t2_20090313.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2008t2_20090311.htm

All images are described in detail on my website.

Can't wait to get real clear, warm, comfortable and dry skies here.
Ups, I am just dreaming from the Arizona desserts in 2004 :)

Clear skies to everybody

Bernhard Häusler
MPC B82

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/index.htm

From:  mark301066 
Subject:  Comet Lulin

Hi there

I've just posted a movie and a processed image of Comet Lulin on 1st
March, taken with LX90 @ f/3.3, SXV-M7C one-shot camera. You can see
them on my website here
lulin-in-leo> .

Any tips on how to better process the image to reveal things like an
anti-tail or any rotational gradients?

Date:  Tue, 17 Mar 2009 23:10:47 +1100
From:  Michael Mattiazzo 
Subject:  C/2009 E1 image March 17 2009
Hi Folks.

I've posted an image of new comet C/2009 E1 Itagaki taken this evening.

http://members.westnet.com.au/mmatti/itagaki.htm

2009 Mar 17.41UT.
15x10 second exposures, Starlight Express MX7c imager + C11 at f/3.3.
A quick visual observation through 25x100mm binoculars has it about
magnitude 10. It was at a very low altitude of 8 degrees.
Slightly enhanced by swan band comet filter.

Cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo

Date:  Tue, 17 Mar 2009 22:24:57 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image of comet C/2009 E1 (Itagaki) at March, 17 2009
Hello comet friends,

today we have the first real clear night here in Germany since 4 weeks.

I took a series of 21 images, 1 min each after twilight ending.

The coma has a complex structure with different shells.

A thin tail is also visible, about 5 min. long in PA 79°

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2009e1_20090317.htm

Clear skies

Bernhard Häusler

MPC B82

Date:  Sat, 21 Mar 2009 05:13:05 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  comet 116P/Wild with an 14' tail at March,20 2009
Dear comet friends,

last night I wanted to know, how the anti-tail was developing. So I
integrated 230 minutes and found an 14 tail in PA 288°:

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/116p_20090320.htm

Clear skies

Bernhard Häusler, Maidbronn, Germany

MPC B82

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

I also last night I noticed that this comet has a antitail.

regards

Da: "Bernd Husler"

integrated 230 minutes and found an 14' tail in PA 288:

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/116p_20090320.htm

Bernhard Husler, Maidbronn, Germany

Date:  Sat, 21 Mar 2009 10:42:02 -0400
From:  Takbounorca@aol.com
Subject:  Tail of comet 19P and antitail 116P.

Hello,

I also took an image of comet 116P. _http://napac.free.fr/_
(http://napac.free.fr/)
23x120s
Teleobjectif sigma Apo 300 mm F/4 +CCD Audine Kaf 3200 ME.
Despite the material we see a antitail.

An image of the comet 19P/Borrelly the tail is visible.
20x120s
Teleobjectif sigma Apo 300 mm F/4 +CCD Audine Kaf 3200 ME.

S.Takbou
Clear skies

Observatoire de l'ancienne abbaye
N 50°52'48"
E 02°28'18"
Altitude 16 m
Wormhout
France
_http://napac.free.fr/_ (http://napac.free.fr/)
MPC A11

Date:  Wed, 25 Mar 2009 09:54:43 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  19P/Borrelly from this morning (March, 25 2009)
Hello comet friends,

19P/Borrelly, taken in the morning hours:

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090325.htm

The comet is passing a group of faint galaxies.

Magnitude limit ~20

The image was processed by CS3, frozen on the comet and the stars.

CS

Bernhard Haeusler

MPC B82

Saludos, Gustavo Muler.

Observatorio Nazaret, MPC J47

http://www.astrosurf.com/nazaret/

Mike,

This is my recent visual estimate, as reference:

22P/Kopff:
2009 Mar. 22.18 UT: m1=10.8, Dia.=3.5', DC=2/, 20 cm SCT (100x) ( Alto
del Castro - Aralla, alt. 1720 m, Len, N. Spain ).

Clear skies,

J. J. Gonzalez

Date:  Sun, 05 Apr 2009 16:03:58 -0000
From:  Dave Kodama 
Subject:  Comet Lulin wrap up
Bad weather has been plaguing my astrophotography attempts this winter, especially frustrating my attempts to take shots of Comet Lulin. It looks like I've taken my last shot of that comet as it's rapidly fading out of the range of my scopes now, so here's my meager collection:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2009/lulin/

Here's my last shot (last weekend) of Comet Lulin fading in Gemini:

http://www.eanet.com/kodama/astro/2009/0328/

Dave

Date:  Thu, 09 Apr 2009 17:04:53 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Three Comets in Gemini
Last night I imaged three comets in Gemini:
C/2007 N3 Lunin mag 9.1
144P Kushida, mag 11.5
C/2006 OF2 Broughton mag 12.2

Epsilon 160 f/3.3, SXV-H9 camera binned 2x2.

Conditions were terrible  full moon and VLM ~ 2.0 in the imaging sector due to sky glow. But I've not been able to image for many months, so I needed practice.

OF2 was right on top of a bright star, so its image was not successful. In retrospect, I'd have been better off going for T2 Cardinal in nearby Auriga at magnitude 9.8. I was pushing saturation with meager 90 second exposures with so much background light.

Images, associated data, and imaging notes at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Pier Design Paper: http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm 

Date:  Thu, 09 Apr 2009 22:09:04 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image of C/2009 F6 (Yi-SWAN) at 2009-04-09
Hi comet friends,

here an image of this evening:

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2009f6.htm

20 x 40 sec. exposure, 2009-04-09, UT 19:18 to 19:34, 12" SCT f-7 + CCD
ST10XME
13.08mag, coma: 3', tail: 1' in PA 337°

Clear skies

Bernhard Haeusler

MPC B82

Date:  Sun, 12 Apr 2009 16:58:06 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  Images of 19P and 74P
Hi all,

inspite of the 94% Moon in 70° distance the complex structure of the inner
and outer tails of 19P are visible quite good.
I wonder how professional images would look like?

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090412.htm

Date:  Mon, 13 Apr 2009 12:30:12 +0200
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Bernd, Rolando, Gustavo

Thank you for compliments. It was the first night with my regular equipment after two months. After observing
session on feb. 5 i had a crash. My car takes a loop and goes to the scrap. The mount fly through the rear window...
It was a big shock. Now - the mount is back and i testing some things. Next week i will go for two weeks to Namibia, for observing.

The image of last night i give a second try. I will post it soon

Michael

Date:  Sat, 18 Apr 2009 01:41:12 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Five Comets in Gemini and Vicinity
Last night I imaged five comets in Gemini and vicinity:
C/2007 N3 Lunin mag 9.6
C/2009 F6 Yi-SWAN mag 9.9
C2008 T2 (Cardinal) mag 11.6
144P Kushida, mag 11.8
116P Wild mag 12.7

Epsilon 160 f/3.3, SXV-H9 camera binned 2x2. Exposures were typically 8 x 4 minutes.

Images, associated data, and imaging notes at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Pier Design Paper: http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm

From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image of C/2005 L3 (Mc Naught) at April, 19 2009
Dear friends,

here you find a new image of this big comet behind the Jupiter orbit:

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2005l3_20090419.htm

The image is processed with CS3 to freeze the comet and the stars.

Clear skies

Bernhard Haeusler

Date:  Mon, 20 Apr 2009 12:34:53 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  comet c/2005 L3 mc naught and galaxies
Hello everybody,

Last Saturday I had the opportunity to image comet C/2005L3 McNaught on the
border Bootes/Canes Venatici. This location assured to have a lot of
Galaxies aside. The image is cropped. Taken with the 12" ASA N and the
Apogee Alta U16 Tracked, not guided :-) with the new ASA DDM 85 direct drive
mount. Total exposure time 3360 seconds. Subs between 420 and 600 seconds.
Seeing was 2,5" average . Again all images are unguided. Just a new feeling
believe me.

You have to zoom in. attention < 2 megabit

HYPERLINK
"http://www.ims.tuwien.ac.at/~rhemann/mcnaught.html"http://www.ims.tuwien.ac
.at/~rhemann/mcnaught.html

Gerald

No virus found in this outgoing message.
Checked by AVG.
Version: 7.5.557 / Virus Database: 270.12.0/2068 - Release Date: 19.04.2009
20:04

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

From:  Warwick Taylor 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] comet c/2005 L3 mc naught and galaxies
Hi, Gerald,

What a beautiful photo!

Regards,
Warwick

> Hello everybody,
>
> Last Saturday I had the opportunity to image comet C/2005L3 McNaught on
> the
> border Bootes/Canes Venatici. This location assured to have a lot of
> Galaxies aside. The image is cropped. Taken with the 12" ASA N and the
> Apogee Alta U16 Tracked, not guided :-) with the new ASA DDM 85 direct
> drive
> mount. Total exposure time 3360 seconds. Subs between 420 and 600 seconds.
> Seeing was 2,5" average . Again all images are unguided. Just a new
> feeling
> believe me.
>
> You have to zoom in. attention < 2 megabit
>
> HYPERLINK
>
"http://www.ims.tuwien.ac.at/~rhemann/mcnaught.html"http://www.ims.tuwien.ac
> .at/~rhemann/mcnaught.html
>
> Gerald
>
> No virus found in this outgoing message.
> Checked by AVG.
> Version: 7.5.557 / Virus Database: 270.12.0/2068 - Release Date:
> 19.04.2009
> 20:04
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>
> ------------------------------------
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>

Date:  Thu, 23 Apr 2009 20:00:20 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet C/2007 N3 Lulin Still a good Target
Comet C/2007 N3 Lulin is fading rapidly into the western sky. But it is still a good target, with a 20 arc minute long tail, magnitude about 9.5, and fairly high in Gemini. It also has an incredibly slow relative motion of only 0.01 arc seconds/minute, so you can take long exposures without blurring the comet.

Last night I imaged it under terrible seeing, but fortunately one doesn't need good seeing to image a comet. When I focus using AstroArt 3.0, a medium bright (mag 8 star) lights up just one pixel in focus mode. Last night the focus image was bouncing back and forth between 4 and 7 pixels! Probably 6 or 7 arc second RMS seeing. But I got a reasonable image at 5.0 arc seconds per pixel (binned 2x2).

My sky brightness was 19.0 magnitudes/ square arc second (measured with a Sky Quality Meter, as my 68 year old eyes aren't very sensitive any more). That translates into an NELM (naked-eye limiting magnitude) of about 4.7. I live 40 miles west of Chicago.

Images, associated data, and imaging notes at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Pier Design Paper: http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm

Date:  Sun, 26 Apr 2009 10:49:58 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  two weak comets: 33P and C/2007 T5 (Gibbs) April 24/25 2009
Hi friends,

33P is still in the outgoing stage of its outburst from February and is
reaching actually 19 mag.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/33p_20090424.htm

C/2007 T5 Gibbs is very already very weak with about 19.5 mag.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007t5_20090425.htm

Clear skies to everybody

Bernhard Haeusler

MPC B82

To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tuesday, April 28, 2009, 10:21 PM

Have completely re-done my web site, link below for anyone interested. I'm not pretending it's anything more than a comet junkie's rather average shots though!!
http://robsastropic s.googlepages. com/comets

Also comet C/2008 Q3 Garradd taken last night in fairly poor conditions (atmospheric moisture):
http://robsastropic s.googlepages. com/cometc2008q3 garradd

Cheers -

Rob

Date:  Thu, 30 Apr 2009 18:10:29 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  some new images of 29P and comet Broughton of April
Hi,
29P with its small outburst of around 1 mag, detected by Gustavo Muler:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/29p.htm
The RGB color image of April 21 shows a white, dense central condensation.

and C/2006 OF2 (Broughton) becoming weaker this month:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2006of2.htm
Clear skies to everybody
Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82

Date:  Sun, 10 May 2009 13:21:31 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image of 19P/Borrelly at May, 07 2009
Dear comet friends,

19P/Borrelly, taken under difficult conditions (Moon, summer atmosphere).
42 x 3 min. exposure, 2009-05-07, UT 21:56 to 00:19, 12" SCT f-6.532 + CCD
ST10XME
17.66 mag, coma: 0'16", main tail: 3'19" in PA 296°

The central condensation seems to have a double structure this day.
May be this is a special bright dust emission in PA 310° in 13 arc seconds
distance of the central condensation. The location of the second peak is
laying on the well known small inner tail in PA 310, which is visible on all
of my images this year.

Detailed analysis under:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090507.htm

Who has another picture of the comet of this day?

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82 

Date:  Sun, 10 May 2009 12:45:08 -0000
From:  Bernhard Häusler 
Subject:  Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images

this is a great show of Southern skies comets!
Very impressive comet images from your journey to Namibia.

Clear skies in Austria
Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82

>
> Regards,
>
> schmidtcamera2500
>

Date:  Mon, 11 May 2009 00:17:59 +0200
From:  francois kugel 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] image of 19P/Borrelly at May, 07 2009
Hello Bernhard,

Here you can find an image from this evening :

http://pagesperso-orange.fr/fkometes/images/comets_img/19P-090051088-12x120.JPG

I can confirm this condensation in the tail.

exp. 12x120sec. Tel 0.5-m F/3+ccd Kai11k (No filter). weather : cloudy.

0019P C2009 05 10.87389 12 31 04.86 +35 24 39.7 18.2 N A77

Francois Kugel
#A77

Date:  Tue, 12 May 2009 18:28:01 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  line profiles of 19P/Borrelly
Dear Francois, dear friends,

here you find the line profiles of my last four images taken under the same
conditions:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090507_profile.htm
A small buckling is already visible on the images of April.
On May 7 the buckling becomes significant and evident. I think, this is the
same effect on Francois Kugel images.
On February still nothing is evident.

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82

Date:  Thu, 14 May 2009 07:33:00 +0930
From:  Ian Musgrave & Peta O'Donohue 
Subject:  C/2009 G1 near Blanco 1
G'Day All

On 14 and 15 May UTC (thats 15 and 16 may here in Australia), comet
C/2009 G1 will pass through the edges of the open cluster Blanco 1.
Despite the waning Moon's light, this may be a good opportunity for
some nice photos.

Cheers! Ian

======================================================
Ian Musgrave Peta O'Donohue, Jack Francis, Michael James and Andrew
Thomas Musgrave
reynella@mira.net http://home.mira.net/~reynella/
Southern Sky Watch http://www.abc.net.au/science/space/default.htm
(scroll down right hand menu)
AstroBlogg http://astroblogger.blogspot.com/
Contributing Editor, Sky & Space
http://www.skyandspace.com.au/public/home.ehtml 

Date:  Fri, 15 May 2009 22:29:42 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  AW: [comets-ml] condensation in a tail of 19P/Borrelly
Dear Giovanni, Paul, Enrico and Ernsto, Dear Francois,

thanks a lot for your follow-up observation of the second knot or second
condensation.

Now we have together three independent observations of the same phenomena.

Your measured distance of 4.7 arcsec in PA 301° at May,15 is matching to the
observations of Francois Kugel (May, 10: 8arcsec in PA 305°) and my own
(May, 7: 13arcsec in PA 310°) and showing anything coming closer to the
central condensation.

Because I also have no idea, what that observation is meaning, I will follow
your suggestion and will notify the CBAT.

I think only professionals can give us a clarifying statement.

Thanks again for sharing this very interesting event of this amazing comet.

Bernhard Haeusler

MPC B82

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/


http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090507.htm

Von: comets-ml@yahoogroups.com [mailto:comets-ml@yahoogroups.com] Im Auftrag
von gvnn64
Gesendet: Freitag, 15. Mai 2009 20:28 in Rimpar
An: comets-ml@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: Re: [comets-ml] condensation in a tail of 19P/Borrelly

Dears Bernhard and Francois,
we performed some follow-up of the interesting feature you evidenced on
comet 19P/Borrelly. Today we found it as well, yet more close to the central
condensation.

Our blog has been updated with some comments about it:
http://tinyurl.com/q3owqy

Don't know if this phenomena is important or not, anyway it's real. Our
suggestion is to notify the CBAT about your find, if you haven't already did
so, with the data you measured.

With kind regards,
Giovanni Sostero, Paul Camilleri, Enrico Prosperi and Ernsto Guido

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 16 May 2009 08:47:00 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

Date:  Sun, 17 May 2009 16:52:00 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  activities of comet 19P/Borrelly
Dear comet friends,

the very special activities of comet 19P/Borrelly are animating me for
grubbing about the old comet C/1999 S4 (LINEAR). Following the link you find
the beauty and the death of the comet, separated only one week.
I don't think, that comet Borrelly will share this fate, but I'm sure, that
there is something rumoring on the comet's surface and close environment.

Clear skies to everybody and thanks a lot to all observers for sharing this
amazing event.
Bernhard Haeusler, MPC B82 Maidbronn

The Beauty and the Death of comet C/1999 S4 (LINEAR):
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c1999s4_20000731.htm

Updated site with actual informations and observations of comet
19P/Borrelly:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090507.htm 

Date:  Sun, 17 May 2009 15:15:44 -0000
From:  Jordi Camarasa 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] activities of comet 19P/Borrelly
Hi Bernhard,

done.

Greetings

%2C%0D%0A%0D%0Afa&source=translation_link> buscar

Observatorio Paus MPC B49

Date:  Sun, 17 May 2009 21:40:50 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  Super massive Supernova 2000ch in NGC 3432 together with 33P/Daniel
Dear friends,

after getting a hint of Seiichi Yoshida and Dr. Andrea Pastorello (Northern
Ireland), I found the Supernova 2000ch on my images of 33P.
33P/Daniel is passing NCG 3432 at April, 24 2009, together with the Super
Massive Supernova 2000ch in NGC 3432.
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/33p_20090424.htm
CS Bernhard B82 Maidbronn

Date:  Tue, 19 May 2009 12:54:34 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image of 19P/Borrelly at May, 18 2009
Hi all,

here is my image of last night:
80 x 3 min. exposure (240 min. total), 2008-05-18 UT 21:11 to UT 01:22
12" SCT f-6.532 + CCD ST10XME

The night was almost perfect with pretty good seeing and clear view.
Average FWHM: 4.0, weakest star on a 3 minute exposure: 19.4 mag

10 x 10 Box magnitudes measured with FOCAS II:
19P: 18.04 (at May, 07: 17.66)
Knot a: 18.30
Knot b: 18.57

The 10 x 10 box method for photometry is not giving the exact magnitude of a
and b condensation.
Knot a seemed to change its magnitude during the four hours session.
Knot b was more constant.

Along the main tail in PA 310° are some knots visible. For astrometry I
measured the knots a and b:
All measurements for the MPC:

0019P C2009 05 18.90568 12 28 35.82 +33 49 51.1 17.9 N
B82
0019P C2009 05 18.94266 12 28 35.35 +33 49 23.4 17.9 N
B82
0019P C2009 05 18.94484 12 28 35.35 +33 49 22.5 17.9 N
B82
0019P C2009 05 18.96008 12 28 35.17 +33 49 10.5 18.0 N
B82
0019P C2009 05 18.97532 12 28 34.94 +33 48 59.0 18.0 N
B82
0019P C2009 05 19.02324 12 28 34.30 +33 48 23.8 18.1 N
B82
0019P C2009 05 19.04284 12 28 34.06 +33 48 09.1 18.2 N
B82
0019P a C2009 05 18.94266 12 28 34.96 +33 49 27.3 18.1 N
B82
0019P a C2009 05 18.94484 12 28 34.93 +33 49 26.8 18.2 N
B82
0019P a C2009 05 19.04936 12 28 33.57 +33 48 12.8 18.6 N
B82
0019P b C2009 05 18.94266 12 28 34.25 +33 49 28.6 18.6 N
B82
0019P b C2009 05 18.94484 12 28 34.21 +33 49 27.7 18.6 N
B82
0019P b C2009 05 19.04936 12 28 32.75 +33 48 14.3 18.5 N
B82

The IAUC 9044 published the observations of Francois Kugel, France, G.
Sostero, P. Camilleri, E. Prosperi, and E. Guido of Italy and my own
observation. Hope you can read it.

Thanks to all observers, who turned attention to 19P/Borrelly the last week.
I think, we should not miss the next nights.

Clear skies to everybody
Bernhard Haeusler, B82 Maidbronn

Date:  Fri, 22 May 2009 18:40:01 -0000
From:  jdilapo 
Subject:  Image 19P Borrelly (150 min.exp.)
Hi All,

I love to image bright comets ... where are they? Anyway, I had sub-par seeing at my observatory last night so I imaged the faint comet 19P Borrelly. The 150 minute exposure(with minimized star trails)includes a calibrated raw image, calibrated raw with linear stretch and a "pretty picture" with a liberal dose of "artistic license."

http://www.geocities.com/jdilapo/Comet-Borrelly-19P-web.jpg

Regards,

Jim

Date:  Sun, 24 May 2009 16:48:42 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  update of the observation of a second condensation / knot in comet 19P/Borrelly's tail
Dear comet friends,

after getting the .fits images of some very kind colleagues and performing
some analysis, I could create a pinboard to compare the different images. To
make sure that we talk about the same thing, I marked the images with
corresponding dimension lines to the used focal lengths and ccd cameras.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090524_analysis.htm

Many thanks to all participating comet observers!

Clear skies to everybody
Bernd Haeusler MPC B82 Maidbronn 

Date:  Mon, 25 May 2009 13:48:44 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image of 19P/Borrelly of May,24
Hi all,
this is a new image of comet 19P/Borrelly:
81 x 3 min. exposure (243 min. total), 2009-05-24 UT 21:03 to UT 01:18 12"
SCT f-6.532 + CCD ST10XME
18.36 mag, coma: 0'07", tail: 7'07" in PA 297°
Some knots are still visible close to the false nucleus in direction to the
main tail.
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090524.htm

Updated analysis of the central condensation:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090524_analysis.htm

CS Bernhard Haeusler B82 Maidbronn 

Date:  Mon, 25 May 2009 21:21:19 -0000

Subject:  C/2006 W3 2009-06-02.0514

Hello,
New Images of C/2006 W3 (Christensen)

http://napac.free.fr/

Image: (50%) 1076x722
Image: Original Size: 2150x1450.

26 exposures of 60 seconds.
Sigma Telephoto APO 300mm F / 4.
Audine Kaf 3200ME.
Ext Temp: 15 ° camera :-25°

S.Takbou

Observatoire de l'ancienne abbaye
N 50°52'48"
E 02°28'18"
Altitude 16 m
Wormhout
France
_http://napac.free.fr/_ (http://napac.free.fr/)
MPC A11

Date:  Mon, 08 Jun 2009 10:41:24 +0200
From:  walcom77 
Subject:  One image : 2 planets, 5 satellites, 1 comet
Hi All

Here You can find our image taken on June 04, 2009 at 09:19 UT of
the rendez-vous between Jupiter, Neptune and the comets 22P/Kopff.
Moreover in the same image you can see the Galileian Satellites and
Neptune's satellite Triton.

The image has been obtained remotely from New Mexico with a wide-field
Tak Sky 106 ED f/5

http://bit.ly/44ghQ

Best Regards

Ernesto Guido & Giovanni Sostero
http://remanzacco.blogspot.com
Italy

Date:  Tue, 09 Jun 2009 20:03:41 +1000
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2008 Q3 Garrad and Omega Centauri
Thanks, ian.
>A lovely image. But how on earth did you find a hole in the near
>constant rain and cloud that has been assaulting us in southern Australia?
You have to just keep looking regularly. I Got lucky again when logging into GRAS, there where clouds early but they parted.
I tried for an RGB image but it is not working out when I process it.

I expect there will be a queue at GRAS, if there are no clouds, on Jun 11 (01:30am local time) as this comet passes by Centaurus A.
This world be a very good color shot to have.

Kind regards, Alan
http://cometal.bigblog.com.au/index.do

Date:  Wed, 10 Jun 2009 19:22:36 +0930
From:  Ian Musgrave & Peta O'Donohue 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2008 Q3 Garrad and Omega Centauri
G'Day All

At 07:33 PM 9/06/2009, Alan wrote:
>Thanks, ian.
> >A lovely image. But how on earth did you find a hole in the near
> >constant rain and cloud that has been assaulting us in southern Australia?
>You have to just keep looking regularly.

Ah, yeas. It was one of those nights though, where regular looking
was not really possible :-(

>I Got lucky again when logging into GRAS, there where clouds early
>but they parted.
>I tried for an RGB image but it is not working out when I process it.

That's a shame

>I expect there will be a queue at GRAS, if there are no clouds, on
>Jun 11 (01:30am local time) as this comet passes by Centaurus A.
>This world be a very good color shot to have.

The observatory roof is currently closed, 7 timer
http://7timer.y234.cn/V3/product.php?language=en&product_id=1&lon=140.3&lat=-34.2&ac=sfc

and Skippy Sky
http://www.skippysky.com.au/Australia/

both predict cloud free times later tonight, when the Moon is high though.

Cheers! Ian

Date:  Thu, 11 Jun 2009 12:31:30 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image of 19P/Borrelly at June,7 2009
Dear comet friends,

here my image of comet 19P/Borrelly. Unfortunately I lost my guiding star
after 94 minutes integration time when some clouds were traversing the sky.
But in these days with very short nights I am happy for each single comet I
can photograph.

94 min. exposure, 2009-06-07 UT 21:20 to 22:54, 12" SCT f-6.532 + ST10XME
18.33 mag, coma 7" in PA 302°

Full Moon at altitude ~10°; distance to the comet: 88° in PA 122°

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090607.htm

Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler B82 Maidbronn

The comet was 5 on the horizon in the twilight.
