http://www.aerith.net/comet/catalog/2008Q3/mag.gif 

Date:  Tue, 16 Jun 2009 12:31:07 +0530
From:  amar sharma 
Subject:  Current Rendezvous - 67/P and OF2

Hello Comet-imagers, I came across in Cartes software regarding close visual approaches of various comets.

A close rendezvous between 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko, C/2006 OF2 (Broughton) and 29P/Schwassmann-Wachmann-1 is ongoing these days. The two comets 67/P and OF2 are less than a degree apart, and 29/P places 4* from the pair.

Additionally, C/2008 T2 (Cardinal) and C/2007 Q3 (Siding Spring) are lower, and 6*-7* away. This is in the low evening twilight sky, so should be good for Northern latitude imagers.

144P/Kushida and 116P/Wild are 6* away, and close to Saturn in Leo.

C/2009 E1 (Itagaki) places 8*-9* from C/2006 W3 (Christensen) which inturn is around 3* from NGC 7331.

19P/Borrelly should serve good for wide-field targets, since it is in the Coma cluster of galaxies (near NGC 4565).

Looking forward for your images. Thanking You.

Amar A. Sharma
+12* 58' / 77E 30'
BAS (www.bas.org.in)
Bangalore, India

Explore and discover exciting holidays and getaways with Yahoo! India Travel http://in.travel.yahoo.com/

Date:  Sat, 20 Jun 2009 13:51:44 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  updated informations of the phenomenons in comet 19P/Borrelly's tail
Dear comet friends,

when I shortly got the knowledge, that the long tail of comet 19P/Borrelly
is a sunward tail, the origin of the knots we observed the last months is
going to a more likely direction.

Thousand thanks to Nalin Samarasinha of the PSI Planetary Science Institute
http://www.psi.edu/
for his very helpful hints concerning our observations.

It is very interesting, that the long tail on our images is a sunward tail
and not the intrinsic tail (I was really shocked when I heard about this).
This means, that the observation normally can't be a fragment, because
non-gravitational forces can push fragments only in the direction of
intrinsic tails effected by solar winds.
To check out the origin of tails it is very recommended to load the
ephemeris table of the JPL (Jet Propulsion Laboratory) on their HORIZONS
Web-Interface. http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons.cgi#top

With the OBSERVER Ephemeris Type and the Table setting feature "Sub Sun Pos,
Ang & Dis" you find the position angle of the comet orientated to the Sun.
So it is easy to find out, that 19P/Borrelly's long tail is a sunward tail.
Based on these knowledge, we can suppose, that the feature we observed the
last months is a dust feature.
This assumption can also be substantiated, if we go back to the DS1 Mission
of the NASA in September 2001.
On the images of the integrated camera on board of the Space probe, two
active polar jets are visible in rough direction to the Sun.
Follow this link please and download the PDF text for free to see the images
(Sign in is nescessary).
http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/296/5570/1087

The new phenomenon is probably a dust feature corresponding to the same
polar sunward orientated jets they observed on the DS1 mission.
Unfortunately I am not able to compute the relationship according to our new
observations because of lacking knowledge in higher mathematics.

For your pleasure here you find an animation of the comet showing its
development between March and June 2009:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_analysis.htm
and here my newest image of June, 16:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090616.htm

Clear skies and many thanks to all helping guys

Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82 Maidbronn

Date:  Wed, 24 Jun 2009 11:50:12 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  June 23rd comet images in UK twilight
Despite the permanent summer twilight here in the UK
I imaged 2006 W3 (Christensen) and 2009 L2 (Yang-Gao)
last night:

http://uk.geocities.com/martin.mobberley@btinternet.com/2006w3_20090623_mpm.jpg

http://uk.geocities.com/martin.mobberley@btinternet.com/2009l2_20090623_mpm.jpg

Comets page:

http://uk.geocities.com/martinmobberley/Comets.html

Regards,
Martin

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 25 Jun 2009 08:54:58 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  new knowledge of comet Borrelly
Dear friends,

Dr. Nalin Samarashina checked the geometry of our May observations and find
out, that the observed jets are coming somewhere from the opposing pole,
which was in darkness in 2001 during the DS1 mission. Actually the Sun is
only about 30° from the opposing pole where somebody could see the Sun in
about 60° altitude from there.

So the scenario is indicating a new activity of the sunward pole right now.
The pole where the jets are coming from during the DS1 mission in 2001 is in
total darkness right now and these former jets can't be the origin of the
actual observations.

Here you find the updated pinboard with an image of Albert Sanchez included:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_20090524_analysis.htm

and here the updated analysis:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/19p_analysis.htm

More images with good S/N are welcome!
Clear skies
Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/

Date:  Fri, 26 Jun 2009 19:42:27 -0000
From:  Efrain Morales 
Subject:  McNaught-NGC5033-June26th, 2009ut
Thanks to Gustavo Muler for the heads up info on his recent image. I took a series of images of 10min ea. a total of 2hrs 27min. of the comet approaching close to the core of the serfert Galaxy NGC5033.
I am working on a animation of the sequences when completed will post.
Clear Skies
Efrain
Jaicoa-Observatory.com

At:http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/album/1050174766/pic/list

From:  Rob 
Subject:  Re: Animation C/2005L3, NGC5033-Posted

Cheers -

Rob

Date:  Sat, 27 Jun 2009 05:11:14 -0000
From:  Dimitry Chestnov 
Subject:  Several comet images
Hi all,

Here is several images shot by me remotely at Tzec Maun observatories H10 (near Mayhill, NM, U.S.A.) and D25 (near Pingelly, Western Australia)

C/2009 FK75 (Lemmon-Siding Spring)
http://tinyurl.com/p2og5e

C/2009 F4 (McNaught)
http://tinyurl.com/oopvfv

C/2008 Q1 (Maticic)
http://tinyurl.com/oky4x5

P/2009 L2 (Yang-Gao)
(D25, 0.18-m Newtonian, sum 2x120 sec RGB, Gaussian intensity scale)
http://tinyurl.com/pjjuj6

C/2006 W3 (Christensen)
(H10, 0.36-m Maksutov-Newtonian + R filter, sum 3x60 sec, 1"/pix. Logarithmic intensity scale: must be close to human eye's perception)
http://tinyurl.com/qpgwqp

Best regards,
Dimitry Chestnov
(Saransk, Russia)

Date:  Sun, 28 Jun 2009 12:29:21 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  AW: [Comet-Images] 22P/Kopff
Hello Francois,

very nice ion tail, congratulation. At the time of your exposure the
geocentric Sun angle of the comet is about 68.4°.

Bernhard Haeusler B82 Maidbronn

Von: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] Im
Auftrag von francois kugel
Gesendet: Sonntag, 28. Juni 2009 12:11 in Rimpar
An: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: [Comet-Images] 22P/Kopff

Hello!
Here you can find an image from 22P/Kopff taking on 2009 06 28.05.
9x120s; T500 F/3

the comet show a long tail about 30' in PA around 250 :

http://astrosurf.com/obsdauban/images/cometes_img/22P-09062805-9x120s-croplo
g.jpg

Francois KUGEL
#A77

Date:  Mon, 29 Jun 2009 10:15:38 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:R: [Comet-Images] 22P/Kopff
Hello all,
thanks to Francois for his nice images about 22P/Koppf.
I think that what we actually see in these pictures is not an ion tail, but another interesting phenomena, related with the forthcoming passage of Earth through the orbita plane of the comet (let's say, a dust phenomena, instead of gas).

Those interested, are invited to perform further follow-up, possibly (but not exclusively) through I and R photometric filters. Please contact me privately for details.

With kind regards,
Giovanni Sostero (CARA, Italian Comet Section)

Date:  Mon, 29 Jun 2009 12:16:35 +0200
From:  "bernhard.haeusler@t-online.de" 
Subject:  AW: [Comet-Images] 22P/Kopff
Hi Francois,

go to the Horizons Site of the JPL:
http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/?horizons

click on "web-interface"
on the next site choose:

Ephemeris Type: Observer
Target Body: change to 22P of 2009
Observer Location: Geocentric
Time Span: change to your prefered time span
Table Setting: change and select additionally number 16 "Sub Sun Pos Ang & Dis"
Display/Output: change to html, plain text or download, as you like

The Sun angle you get is the opposite angle of the intrinsic tail at the time of your exposure.
So you can clearly decide, if the tail is an intrinsic tail or a sunward tail.

Good luck
Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82 Maidbronn 

Date:  Mon, 29 Jun 2009 11:32:06 +0100
From:  gustavo muler 
Subject:  C/2008Q3 Garradd.


COMET C/2008 Q3 Garradd
80mm. F/4.7 st8xme unfiltered 20 x 120seg. 366mm.

C/2008 Q3 28/06/2009 22:29:38 12.54 11.62 11.16 10.85 10.64 10.48 28.8 17.2 J47
C/2008 Q3 28/06/2009 22:29:38* 0.01 0.02 0.02 0.02 0.02 0.02 4 10.3 CMC

CARA - Cometas Obs - Observadores Cometas

http://astrosurf.com/nazaret/images/cometas/C2008Q3/C2008Q3-090628-J47.jpg

--
Best regards,
gustavo

www.astrosurf.com/nazaret

gustavomuler@telefonica.net

Date:  Mon, 29 Jun 2009 16:53:31 +0200
From:  francois kugel 
Subject:  Re: R: R: [Comet-Images] 22P/Kopff 2009 06 29.10
Thank you Toni,

If you observe this comet try to use I or R filter to verify if this is a ion
tail or more probably a dust train along the orbita plane of the comet as
Giovanni suggests it.

Clear sky,
Francois

Date:  Mon, 29 Jun 2009 17:09:06 +0200
From:  Toni Scarmato 
Subject:  R: R: R: [Comet-Images] 22P/Kopff 2009 06 29.10
Hi Francois.

Yes in my observations of comets I use an Rc filter. I agree the tail
appear to be a strange structure for to be a ions tail.

Long and thin, the probability that is a dust trail is high.

At more soon I hope to can to take a series of images of the comet.

Regards,

Toni

Da: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] Per

> 1° (around 0.015 UA)in PA 254 +/-1°.
>
http://astrosurf.com/obsdauban/images/cometes_img/22P-09062910-12x120s-cropl

>
l>
> og.jpg
>
> Best regards,
> Francois
> #A77
>

> >
> > Very good image Francois, that comet will be my next target.
> >
> > Toni
> >

personal opinion is lead to serious errors in processing LS ....

?

Date:  Mon, 29 Jun 2009 20:28:54 -0000
From:  gustavo_muler 
Subject:  Re: 22p kopff -  C/2005 l3 - ngc 5033
Hello my friends.

in spain, the word "GUSANO"
as someone from spain call me, is a very hard insult, mr. Sherwood.
that´s maybe why some spanish friends tell pina to do not use this words.
it is not an mistake.

call

gustavo
gusano

are not the same.
and is not a name in spanish.

my apologize in the name of my friends, and I hope Mr. Pina can as well spell names propertly.

imagine that if someone calls you badly, you are not going to answer this anymore, and this will be my point of view, this "jokes(?)" only places spanish observers in a bad situation, and it began with a very hard insult (not confusion) to my person.

best regards, gustavo.

Date:  Mon, 29 Jun 2009 21:11:30 -0000
From:  gustavo_muler 
Subject:  Re: 22p kopff -  C/2005 l3 - ngc 5033
of course, Clay !
I Pretend to be polite, and I din´t read it twice.
but, as we can see, sherwood, has not any bad or unpolite meaning in english.

gusano, is worm, and in spanish, is someone very bad and minimum unpolite word to trate someone (have a look in the diccionary).
we know all of us the one that insult me and there is nothing else to say about it from me.
Clay, I don´t like this kid´s games, and I am sure the idea of this list is not to kid´s discussions.
I thought the idea was showing pictures the bes as we can.
best regards, gustavo.
my apologize again.

Date:  Mon, 29 Jun 2009 16:24:52 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: 22p kopff -  C/2005 l3 - ngc 5033
No need whatsoever to apologize; a man' name is his integrity and all people should
remember and respect that. I honestly think that - like Mr. Holloway stated - it was an
error in translation. The internet is a cruel communicator and when one language is
required to be read as another, it makes the communication even less personal and in many
cases, more threatening.

I think that we all have the highest respect for you and the work that you do....I know
that I do.

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

Date:  Mon, 29 Jun 2009 22:01:36 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: 22p kopff -  C/2005 l3 - ngc 5033
Gustavo. As you can see, I don't know about the crossing of names such as you have pointed out. The translator programs leave me most times with a less than accurate idea of what someone has actually meant. No disrespect will be tolorated by me from anyone on this board towards another. There are private ways to carry on a war without invloving the members of this board. If anyone feels like they are being kicked around without cause or with cause they should contact me in private and I will deal with it. The greatest group of comet imagers in the world are posting there work and that is the way it will stay, a safe place to visit and post.

Keep up the good work!
Mike Holloway
Moderator

Mr Pina.

You are no virgin to past trouble, just like me. We have been around enough years to know the answer already. I know that when the Comet imaging and Comet ML boards are conserned disrespect is not tolerated by anyone or group of people. We will be above that. All are equal here and all will respect the rules! You know I am correct and ask you to be done with this thread, please.

Thanks to all
Mike Holloway 

Date:  Tue, 30 Jun 2009 22:36:46 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  AW: AW: [Comet-Images] 22P/Kopff
Dear Francois,

the long tail on your image is probably an ion tail, as we can observe on
many other comets.

The tail is long, straight, thin and matching very well with the opposite
geocentric sun angle we discussed.

Off course my opinion is corresponding only to my own observations of this
kind of tails till now and can be wrong.

Common dust tails are normally widespread, curved and more diffuse.

Although dust jets are more thinner, they are usually not corresponding to
the geometric angle of the sun position, but they are originated in
morphological situations of the comets surfaces themselves.

Ion tails are originated in light gaseous elements and pushed directly by
the solar wind away.

If there is a sign, that the long thin tail on your fantastic image is
originated from a dust jet phenomenon, that will be a real surprise for me
and would be very interesting.

Off course I would never exclude that assumption from the beginning and will
patiently wait for good arguments.

See you and continue your great work.

Bernhard Haeusler

B82 Maidbronn

Von: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] Im
Auftrag von francois kugel
Gesendet: Montag, 29. Juni 2009 16:01 in Rimpar
An: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: Re: AW: [Comet-Images] 22P/Kopff

Hello Bernhard,
many thank's , it work correctly!
Différence betwen the theorical angle and my mesurements is around 4 to
5°...
maybe Giovanni is in the right!
It is interesting to continuing theses observations!

Best regards,
Francois

bernhard.haeusler@t-online.de a
écrit :
>
> Hi Francois,
>
> go to the Horizons Site of the JPL:
> http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/?horizons
>
> click on "web-interface"
> on the next site choose:
>
> Ephemeris Type: Observer
> Target Body: change to 22P of 2009
> Observer Location: Geocentric
> Time Span: change to your prefered time span
> Table Setting: change and select additionally number 16 "Sub Sun Pos Ang
> & Dis"
> Display/Output: change to html, plain text or download, as you like
>
> The Sun angle you get is the opposite angle of the intrinsic tail at the
> time of your exposure.
> So you can clearly decide, if the tail is an intrinsic tail or a sunward
> tail.
>
> Good luck
> Bernhard Haeusler
> MPC B82 Maidbronn
>

Date:  Wed, 01 Jul 2009 14:47:26 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:AW: AW: [Comet-Images] 22P/Kopff
> If there is a sign, that the long thin tail on your fantastic image is
> originated from a dust jet phenomenon, that will be a real surprise for me
> and would be very interesting.

Let' say: there are more things in heaven and earth, Bernd,
than are dreamt of in your philosophy. :-)

Get a look at these links:
http://tinyurl.com/ms8nfe
http://tinyurl.com/norbpx
http://tinyurl.com/my6494

All of them refers to "long" and "narrow" features produced by dust phenomena seen under certain cirmunstances.

I'm NOT saying that what Francois has actually captured in his images on 22P/Kopff is indeed a "neck line" structure, but that with the current informations we have we cannot rule out either hypothesis (ion tail, neck like, or a similar stuff) for sure.

Simply more data is needed to decide what's actually that "long" & "narrow" tailward feature.

With kind regards,
Giovanni Sostero

From:  Dimitry Chestnov 
Subject:  Re: Several comet images
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "Dimitry Chestnov" wrote:
>
> C/2006 W3 (Christensen)
> (H10, 0.36-m Maksutov-Newtonian + R filter, sum 3x60 sec, 1"/pix. Logarithmic intensity scale: must be close to human eye's perception)
> http://tinyurl.com/qpgwqp
>

C/2006 W3 reprocessed (Gaussian stretch, noise suppressing in Neat Image):
http://tinyurl.com/n5tpgc

C/2006 W3 (Christensen) on July 1, 2009 (180mm Newtonian, sum 7x120sec, Gaussian stretch, noise suppressing in Neat Image):
http://tinyurl.com/mbylpu

C/2008 Q3 (Garradd) on July 1, 2009 (180mm Newtonian, sum 15x60sec, Gaussian stretch, noise suppressing in Neat Image):
http://tinyurl.com/l4hp38

Date:  Sat, 04 Jul 2009 06:44:59 -0000
From:  Dimitry Chestnov 
Subject:  22P/Kopff - dust trail or ion tail?
Bernhard,

Dust trails consist of heavy dust particles, which are not affected by solar wind or light pressure, and distributed along the orbit ahead and behind the comet. When dust trails of comets cross the Earth's orbit, we see meteror showers.

Clear skies!
Dimitry 

Date:  Sat, 04 Jul 2009 11:30:36 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  AW: [Comet-Images] 22P/Kopff - dust trail or ion tail?
Hello Dimitry,

thanks for the hint. The English word dust trail is matching quite well to
the German word Staubspur or Staubfaehrte  dust along the orbit. Dust
tail means in German Staubschweif.

On Francois image of June, 28 the direction of the observed long tail is
matching quite well to the expected position angle of the intrinsic tail
effected by the solar wind in PA 248.4° (Source: JPL/Horizons). Francois
measured around 250° on his image.

The movement of 22P at June, 28 is 49 in PA 85.9 (opposite angle: 265.9°) 
are these the PAs of the dust trail?

Giovanni Sostero may be right, if he suppose the tail is possibly the
intrinsic dust tail and influenced by the neck line effect. But it can also
be an ion tail or a mixture of dust and ion.

In every case this is a very nice and interesting observation of Francois!

Unfortunately I cant take images of the comet from my location right now.

Clear skies

Bernhard Haeusler

Von: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com] Im
Auftrag von Dimitry Chestnov
Gesendet: Samstag, 4. Juli 2009 08:45 in Rimpar
An: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Betreff: [Comet-Images] 22P/Kopff - dust trail or ion tail?

Bernhard,

Dust trails consist of heavy dust particles, which are not affected by solar
wind or light pressure, and distributed along the orbit ahead and behind the
comet. When dust trails of comets cross the Earth's orbit, we see meteror
showers.

Clear skies!
Dimitry

Date:  Wed, 08 Jul 2009 12:07:51 -0000
From:  Rob 
Subject:  C/2008 Q3 & M104 close conjunction
Very rough, sorry. Bright moonlight & an RA drive behaving very erratically. Only ended up with 1 good and 3 'usable' subs out of 12.

4 x 23 sec, piggybacked Canon 400D at 200mm, ISO 1600, F/6.3. 8 July 09, 10:45 UT. Separation of comet & galaxy 56' 47". Will be closer tomorrow night.

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/M104Q38July0910-45UTcrop.jpg

Cheers -

Rob 

Date:  Wed, 08 Jul 2009 12:41:00 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Faint Comets & DSLR
Hello. Well my TV127is has been sent back to the maker to correct the optics which have been off I think sence I bought the scope. This has cause me to only be able to use 1/2 of the chip when imaging. Very strange. In the time untill it returns I am setting a DSLR on the mount. I have a 35/70 zoom and a 100/300 zoom lense. Can anyone give opinion of which or what power to use if I were to search for or images faint comets now known or unknown? I have never searched for new object but there could be a green smudge show up. Any input on time of exp., power of lense used problems to look for, anything.
Contact on list or in private.
Thanks
Mike H. 

Date:  Wed, 08 Jul 2009 04:52:53 -1000
From:  Carey Johnson 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Faint Comets & DSLR

200mm f/2.8

http://www.dailyastronomy.com/story.asp?ID=181311&Title=Amateur+Astronomer+Discovers+Comet+with+Digital+SLR

http://www.aaa.org/index1.aspx?BD=9765

The lower the f/ the better.

Carey

Date:  Thu, 09 Jul 2009 10:44:23 -0000
From:  Burkhard Leitner 
Subject:  Re: Faint Comets & DSLR
Hello Mike,

here is a small overview about the comet discoveries with telelenses from the past years:

C/2003 T3 (Tabur): 180mm (focal length);
C/2004 R2 (ASAS): 200mm ;
C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski): 180mm ;
C/2007 E2 (Lovejoy): 200mm ;
C/2007 K5 (Lovejoy): 200mm ;
C/2008 C1 (Chen-Gao): 200mm ;
C/2009 F6 (Yi-SWAN): 90mm ;
P/2009 L2 (YANG-GAO): 300mm.

Everything between 100mm and 300mm focal length is suitable, but one needs a lot of luck and/or numerous hours of work.

Good luck!

Kind Regards
Burkhard Leitner 

Date:  Thu, 09 Jul 2009 17:46:21 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Faint Comets & DSLR
Thanks. That is very interesting and informative. I would not expect to discover a new object but you never know. Much more involved record keeping would be required for me.
Thanks, Mike H.

>
> here is a small overview about the comet discoveries with telelenses from the past years:
>
> C/2003 T3 (Tabur): 180mm (focal length);
> C/2004 R2 (ASAS): 200mm ;
> C/2006 A1 (Pojmanski): 180mm ;
> C/2007 E2 (Lovejoy): 200mm ;
> C/2007 K5 (Lovejoy): 200mm ;
> C/2008 C1 (Chen-Gao): 200mm ;
> C/2009 F6 (Yi-SWAN): 90mm ;
> P/2009 L2 (YANG-GAO): 300mm.

Date:  Fri, 10 Jul 2009 07:38:55 -0000
From:  discoverer98 
Subject:  What is this?
Hi,
Yesterday morning, July 9th between the hours of midnight and 3am EST I took this 2 hour exposure of M51 ( go to photos album A Comet Watcher)looking for novae in it or other surrounding galaxies but instead found this faint (mag 18.2) object travelling through the image above yellow arrow to left of M 51. Must enlarge to largest image to see it as object is very faint.
I have accounted for all galaxies down to Mag 18.65 and searched the Guide software for possible asteroid or comet but can not account for what this faint object might be. Anyone have an idea? BTW image taken with a Canon XTi which may illustrate what a DSLR can do on faint objects as discussed in previous posts.
Also tried to take follow up images tonight but too cloudy here in Michigan.
Patrick 

Date:  Fri, 10 Jul 2009 10:00:28 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] What is this?
Hello Patrick,
from the picture you poster in the photo album, it's very hard to see anything. Please, can you provide a link to a high-res image?
Cheers,
Giovanni Sostero 

Date:  Fri, 10 Jul 2009 20:48:51 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] What is this?
For situations like this you really need to use the MinorPlanetChecker of the Minor Planet Center. This includes all known minor
planets, with the latest orbits. Any other approach to identifying minor planets is sub-optimal.

http://scully.harvard.edu/~cgi/CheckMP

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

----- Original Message -----
From: "discoverer98"
To:
Sent: Friday, July 10, 2009 5:38 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] What is this?

> Hi,
> Yesterday morning, July 9th between the hours of midnight and 3am EST I took this 2 hour exposure of M51 ( go to photos album A
> Comet Watcher)looking for novae in it or other surrounding galaxies but instead found this faint (mag 18.2) object travelling
> through the image above yellow arrow to left of M 51. Must enlarge to largest image to see it as object is very faint.
> I have accounted for all galaxies down to Mag 18.65 and searched the Guide software for possible asteroid or comet but can not
> account for what this faint object might be. Anyone have an idea? BTW image taken with a Canon XTi which may illustrate what a
> DSLR can do on faint objects as discussed in previous posts.
> Also tried to take follow up images tonight but too cloudy here in Michigan.

Date:  Fri, 10 Jul 2009 23:20:27 +0900
From:  Masayuki Suzuki

Hello,
possibility of a ghost (reflection) of the 7mag star (HIP#66004)
just outside of the left frame?
Masayuki Suzuki

----- Original Message -----
Hi,
Yesterday morning, July 9th between the hours of midnight and 3am EST I took this 2 hour exposure of M51 ( go to photos album A
Comet Watcher)looking for novae in it or other surrounding galaxies but instead found this faint (mag 18.2) object travelling
through the image above yellow arrow to left of M 51. Must enlarge to largest image to see it as object is very faint.
I have accounted for all galaxies down to Mag 18.65 and searched the Guide software for possible asteroid or comet but can not
account for what this faint object might be. Anyone have an idea? BTW image taken with a Canon XTi which may illustrate what a DSLR
can do on faint objects as discussed in previous posts.
Also tried to take follow up images tonight but too cloudy here in Michigan.
Patrick 

Date:  Fri, 10 Jul 2009 08:30:43 -0600
From:  Alan Hale 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] What is this?
Hi everyone,

>
> Hello,

> just outside of the left frame?
> Masayuki Suzuki

>From a quick look at things, I believe I have to agree with Masayuki. If
you'll check the DSS images, this object appears to be precisely in line
with the westward diffraction spike from the star Masayuki mentioned.

Sincerely,

Alan

Date:  Sat, 11 Jul 2009 04:13:34 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: What is this?
1. I doubt it is an internal refl;ection. I've never seen a reflection having the appearance thee shown.
2. A check of the MPC checker (checking some 415000 objects) shows nothing within the region.
3. On close inspection of the image, I have severe reservations about whether what you have identified is a moving object. It
looks more like two close stars with background noise. As with any moving object, two images should be take, to establish
movement.

Finally in situations like this. To make it easier for others to follow up (and not waste their time), you should:
1 specify the date time of the image in UTC. Don't assume that people know what the time zone correction is for your location. I
had to guess;
2. you should estimate the object's location. Tools like GoogleSky should make it easy for you to estimate the RA and Dec.
3. Of course, if you have the UTC and approximate RA and Dec, you can then do your own check against the MPC Minor Planet Checker.

Dave Herald
Canberra, Australia

Date:  Fri, 10 Jul 2009 13:05:10 -0600
From:  Alan Hale 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: What is this?
Hi again everyone,

Neither the red nor the blue second-generation DSS images show anything at
this location, even though they both show objects fainter than the limiting
magnitude of the image. If this is anything real, it must be something new.
However, the fact that it is an exact east-west trail, and is precisely due
west of the bright star that Masayuki identified, leads me to believe that
it is a reflection of some kind.

That being said, it probably wouldn't hurt for someone to do some follow-up
on it. Unfortunately, I'm not set up for that right now . . .

Sincerely,

Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: Rob
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, July 08, 2009 10:07 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] C/2008 Q3 & M104 close conjunction

Very rough, sorry. Bright moonlight & an RA drive behaving very erratically. Only ended up with 1 good and 3 'usable' subs out of 12.

4 x 23 sec, piggybacked Canon 400D at 200mm, ISO 1600, F/6.3. 8 July 09, 10:45 UT. Separation of comet & galaxy 56' 47". Will be closer tomorrow night.

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/M104Q38July0910-45UTcrop.jpg

Cheers -

Rob

Date:  Fri, 17 Jul 2009 21:05:10 -0000
From:  Dennis Persyk 
Subject:  Comet C/2006 W3 Cristensen
My sky brightness was 18.7 magnitudes/ square arc second (measured with a Sky Quality Meter, as my 68 year old eyes aren't very sensitive any more). That translates into an NELM (naked-eye limiting magnitude) of about 5.0, or Bortel 6. I live 40 miles west of Chicago.

I was disappointed that I could barely see it in my 11-inch Celestron SCT. I wonder if other visual observers have had any better luck, I have posted a "digital sketch" of what I saw though the eyepiece at the link below to give you an idea of the visual conditions.

Images, associated data, and imaging notes at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo (now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Pier Design Paper: http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm

Date:  Sun, 19 Jul 2009 04:51:32 +0000
From:  Ramon Naves 
Subject:  TRANSITO HD189733
Ayer hizo una noche excepcional , que me permitio captar, el que de
momento es el mejor transito de cuantos he hecho
Lo he recortado para visualizar mejor la parte del transito

La desviacion estandar ronda durante todo el transito 1.5 milesimas
(agrupando las medidas de 3 en 3)

En la parte recta sin transito la desviacion estandar se mantiene por
debajo de las 2 milesimas aunque se agrupe de 20 en 20 medidas

Tomas de 2 minutos con filtro fotometrico R , empece 3 horas antes del
transito y termine unas 2 horas despues.

----------

----------

Stardate : 20090718
Object : hd189733
Observer : Naves, Ramon NR2
E-mail : ramonnaves@telefonica.net
Location : Spain
Latitude : +42.51
Elongitude : +2.40
Aperture : 12-inch
Filter : R
Exposure : 120 sec
ClkCorrn : 0 sec
MAGNITUD DIFERENCIAL

Date:  Sun, 19 Jul 2009 13:27:17 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  comet 22P
Hi at all, at this address

http://comete.uai.it/comete/22P_090719.jpg

I have inserted my latest image of the comet 22P

I find it interesting thin tail, visible with the Rc filter.
interesting activities in the false nucleus too, where it is visible a small jet
that distorts the inner coma.

best regards
Rolando Ligustri
===============================
C.A.R.A. http://cara.uai.it
CAST: Circolo AStrofili Talmassons
www.castfvg.it/fotoccd.htm#comete

Description : 2006 W3 jul 28 UT 23.12 L-270 sec RGB 100:100:110 2x2 bin , M.Jger

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/michael%20jaeger/2006w320090728net2.jpg

http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/general.htmlfiles

schmidtcamera2500

Date:  Fri, 07 Aug 2009 23:01:56 +0200
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Mike

If the comet is faster than 1"/min i always use 2x2 bin. for RGB. This brings better saturation at short time.

best regards
Michael

Date:  Wed, 12 Aug 2009 02:09:49 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /rig-kent-suspect-1-sm-2l.avi
Uploaded by : algwat
Description : Rigil Kentaurus suspect green object, seeking opinions on wether this is more likly an internal reflection, Canon 450d 200MM lens, 30sec exp for each frame seperated by about 2 mins, unguided on EQ6 mount. regards Alan

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/rig-kent-suspect-1-sm-2l.avi

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/general.htmlfiles

Regards,

algwat 

Date:  Wed, 12 Aug 2009 07:13:00 -0000
From:  Rob 
Subject:  Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
No idea Alan, but if it is a real object it would be moving at around a very fast 90 arcseconds per minute, assuming 8 mins between first and last exposure. So 24 hours later at that speed it would be some 36 deg away, down in Carina!! It appears diffuse, unlike an NEA or satellite. I'd be plumping for some kind of lens artefact, not that I fully understand the optics that might produce it. Hope someone can come up with a satisfactory answer for you!

Cheers -

Rob

From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images
Thanks rob,
tried another sequence tonight, still there, definitely is a green internal reflection in the 200mm lens and camera.
I had the camera upside down this time.

kind regards, Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: Rob
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, August 12, 2009 5:13 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: New file uploaded to Comet-Images

No idea Alan, but if it is a real object it would be moving at around a very fast 90 arcseconds per minute, assuming 8 mins between first and last exposure. So 24 hours later at that speed it would be some 36 deg away, down in Carina!! It appears diffuse, unlike an NEA or satellite. I'd be plumping for some kind of lens artefact, not that I fully understand the optics that might produce it. Hope someone can come up with a satisfactory answer for you!

Cheers -

Rob

From:  francois kugel 
Subject:  22P/Kopff trail.
Hello,

Here you can find my last picture of 22P/Kopff and his fine and long tail :

http://astrosurf.com/obsdauban/pages/cometes.html#09-08-15

2009-08-15.97 18x120sec.
FOV= 72'x33'
Mag. = 13.4 (dia = 20")
Trail is 120' long on the picture in PA 230

0022P C2009 08 15.95394 22 55 54.32 -12 34 42.3 13.4 N A77

Clear sky!

Francois KUGEL

Date:  Wed, 26 Aug 2009 15:36:12 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  C/2006 W3 - 08/26/2009
Helo. I am still working on the field of the 127is. Received it back from the factory and attached the large FF and A300 DSLR. This is 6 minutes of exposure using the whole chip but reduced to 33% (1650 pix wide from 3900) of original size. I am really liking a scope that is finally producing a correct star field or close. It is a stack on the stars so comet movement is visible.
Thanks, Mike H.
http://www.fototime.com/BE1D90AA70D33A0/orig.jpg

Date:  Mon, 31 Aug 2009 18:02:39 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  C/2006 W3 Christensen
Although the head is very bright, the surrounding 3-4 arc-minute coma is faint, and there is yet no evidence of a tail, at least not in my images. The comet is embedded in a dense star field in Aquila now. Additionally, the nearly-full moon is 34 degrees away. It is still an easy imaging target.

Images, associated data, and imaging notes at
http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm

Thank you for visiting my site.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo (now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL

Pier Design Paper: http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm

Time Stamp: 2009 09 02, 10:13:32 UT

http://twitpic.com/g6xmk

Astrometrica track and stack of 12 images
Appears as round smudge about 10 arc sec diameter - diffuse in each image
magnitude 17.1N
Red photometric filter

Special thanks and congratulations to Robert McNaught for finding this new morning comet.

Being his 50th discovery, this is his "Golden Discovery"

Is this also a Guiness World Record for comet discoveries by an individual?

Best wishes all,

Charles

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47 

Date:  Wed, 02 Sep 2009 19:23:21 -0000

Subject:  For Your

Don't cover the links. I contacted the yahoo people about this and beleive it or not there is a concern. I have been bumped 3 times to the ones in the know. Hopefully the links will be shortened or channeled to be a single link for a single click. If not now in the future. For now copy and paste these links for the images.
Have a nice day!
Mike H.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sun, 06 Sep 2009 05:43:56 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Twitter and comet imaging
I would love to make contact with other fellow comet imagers and astronomers on Twitter.

Its a nice way to keep up with one another. Its very simple to do.

You can meet up with interesting people all over the world. You send out your message in your native language. Twitter client programs translate for you. All very nice. I follow someone from Israel who sends out his posts, called tweets, in Hebrew. I use Tweetdeck to translate his tweets. No more language barrier.

There are so many web applications now for sharing images. One called Twitpic is very handy. You upload an image either from the web or via cell phone, and add a comment and Twitpic sends out a short web link to the picture with the comment automatically as a Tweet.

Its actually kind of fun, even a little addictive. Its all meant for sharing info and improving communication in a social way. If scientists and astronomers did that more, everyone would benefit. Everyone has something to share.

You can say whatever you want. Tweets are short messages no longer than 140 characters. People can follow you if they want or unfollow as they please. They can reply or just follow along. Its a simple process. I find that most people have very interesting things to say and share. It can generate interest in astronomy and you can learn about other things going on all over.

Even more innovative, is that event reporting can be almost instantaneous. I frequently read breaking news BEFORE its reported on cable TV news or mainline news media.

So if something is happening right now, you can tweet about it and followers anywhere, can read it now, not later. Twitpic lets you see new things happening as they happen.

Charles

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Twitpic: http://twitpic.com/photos/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47

I did not mention Facebook, but its just as big and entertaining.

Date:  Sat, 12 Sep 2009 12:19:23 +1200
From:  John Drummond 
Subject:  CCD comet images with pin-point stars
Hi there,

I have an SBIG STL11000M CCD and 41cm Newtonian. I use this combination for astrophotography but for cometography I tend to put my Canon 350D DSLR camera on as the stars don't end up as RGB streaks when combined. I'm wondering if someone could tell me how to combine comet images taken with the CCD instead so that the comet and stars are all still and pin-point, i.e. no movement. I'd rather take comet images through my CCD as I can get astrometry as well.

Can anyone give me some pointers? Michael Jager, et el perhaps?

Cheers

John Drummond
Possum Observatory (IAU Code: E94)
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 177� 53', S 38� 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Sat, 12 Sep 2009 07:26:50 +0200
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] CCD comet images with pin-point stars
Hi John

Take a look on this site

http://astrophoton.com/tips/comet_images.pdf

Michael

----- Original Message -----
From: "John Drummond"
To:
Sent: Saturday, September 12, 2009 2:19 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] CCD comet images with pin-point stars

Hi there,

I have an SBIG STL11000M CCD and 41cm Newtonian. I use this combination for
astrophotography but for cometography I tend to put my Canon 350D DSLR
camera on as the stars don't end up as RGB streaks when combined. I'm
wondering if someone could tell me how to combine comet images taken with
the CCD instead so that the comet and stars are all still and pin-point,
i.e. no movement. I'd rather take comet images through my CCD as I can get
astrometry as well.

Can anyone give me some pointers? Michael Jager, et el perhaps?

Date:  Sat, 12 Sep 2009 08:35:09 +0200
From:  Stefan Beck 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] CCD comet images with pin-point stars
-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----
Hash: SHA1

Hi John,

try DeepSkyStacker http://deepskystacker.free.fr/english/index.html and
read the manual.

The software has a special comet stacking feature that stacks the stars
and the comet to get pinpoint stars and a "pinpoint" comet.

> Hi there,
>
> I have an SBIG STL11000M CCD and 41cm Newtonian. I use this combination for astrophotography but for cometography I tend to put my Canon 350D DSLR camera on as the stars don't end up as RGB streaks when combined. I'm wondering if someone could tell me how to combine comet images taken with the CCD instead so that the comet and stars are all still and pin-point, i.e. no movement. I'd rather take comet images through my CCD as I can get astrometry as well.
>
> Can anyone give me some pointers? Michael Jager, et el perhaps?

Date:  Sat, 12 Sep 2009 13:18:21 -0400
From:  Charlie Trump 
Subject:  Image of Christensen 210P
Hi All

I do not post many of my comet images but this one I think is special.
As I was setting up to take a image
of Christensen 210P last night I noticed it was moving within a circle
of stars. I took several images waiting
for Christensen 210P to get close to the center and captured this image.
Here is a link to it if you would like
to see it.
http://www.ct-computerservice.com/Comet%20Christensen%20210P.htm

Thanks
C T

I was getting rained on at that time . . . :(

Sincerely,

Alan

Hi John,

and the comet to get pinpoint stars and a "pinpoint" comet

----- Original Message -----
From: "John Drummond"
To:
Sent: Saturday, September 12, 2009 2:19 AM
Subject: [Comet-Images] CCD comet images with pin-point stars

Hi there,

I have an SBIG STL11000M CCD and 41cm Newtonian. I use this combination for
astrophotography but for cometography I tend to put my Canon 350D DSLR
camera on as the stars don't end up as RGB streaks when combined. I'm
wondering if someone could tell me how to combine comet images taken with
the CCD instead so that the comet and stars are all still and pin-point,
i.e. no movement. I'd rather take comet images through my CCD as I can get
astrometry as well.

Can anyone give me some pointers? Michael Jager, et el perhaps?

Cheers

John Drummond
Possum Observatory (IAU Code: E94)
Gisborne, New Zealand
E 177° 53', S 38° 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm

Date:  Wed, 16 Sep 2009 13:00:40 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  88P Howell & NGC 5897, 16 Sept 09
Image of 88P near globular cluster NGC 5897 tonight - separation 1 deg 27'. 10:00, 16 September 2009 UT. First image stacked in Comet mode in DSS. Second image (just the comet) stacked on comet head in Registax. Canon 400D, 200mm, 7 x 75 sec.

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/88p16Sept09DSScscrop.jpg
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/88p16sept0910-00UTRchcrop.jpg

Cheers -

Rob
http://robsastropics.googlepages.com/comets 

Date:  Wed, 16 Sep 2009 16:31:19 -0000
From:  astroched 
Subject:  C/2007 N3 (Lulin)
Today's image of C/2007 N3 taken remotely at Tzec Maun Observatory (near Mayhill, NM, U.S.A.).

0.41-m f/9 Ritchey-Chretien + 6K CCD (3x binning)
Sum of 2 frames 300 sec each, exponential stretch.

http://tinyurl.com/pz7f2c

Date:  Sat, 19 Sep 2009 17:55:10 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Comet C/2008 P1  Good News/Bad News
The Good News:
Comet C/2008 P1 is the only comet in the sky right now with a nice long tail. I imaged it last night with a 4-arc minute long beautiful tail. Unlike C/2006 W3 which everyone is currently imaging and is just a round ball of luminosity, P1 has a real tail and looks like a real comet.

The Bad News:
Whereas tail-less W3 is a healthy magnitude 8.3, P1 is a dim little mag 15.4. Combine that with the skyglow from Chicago about 40 miles east giving me a NELM of about mag 3.5, and you have a real imaging challenge. But I did it!!!!!!!!

I used a Takahashi E-160 astrograph which is a fast f/3.3 and a Starlight Xpress SXV-H9 camera binned 2x2. I could only image for 3 minutes before I ran into sky glow saturation (mine is not a dark site). I only took four exposures, because when I looked at the raws in the observatory monitor I couldn't see the comet. It was only later in the house when I processed the images in ImagesPlus that I saw I had captured it. Darn. I wish I had taken more frames now.

Anyway, images of this dim little fellow with a tail and accompanying documentation are at http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/new.htm I hope you'll check it out.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL 

Date:  Sun, 20 Sep 2009 02:45:51 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  88P Howell, 18 September 2009
88P in Libra, 10:55, 18 Sept 09 UT. Canon 400D unfiltered, 200mm, 7 x 75 sec. Field width 2 deg 9'. Excellent sky conditions.

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/88P18Sept09blank.jpg

Cheers -

Rob
http://robsastropics.googlepages.com/comets

Subject:  88P/Howell 2009-09-21.77


Hello,

An image of 88P/Howell from this evening (10 hight)

http://astrosurf.com/obsdauban/images/cometes_img/88P-09092177-10x30s-croplog.jpg

The comet seem to show a tail 1.25'long in PA 240.

88P : 2009-09-21.77 Tel 0.5-m F/3 + ccd kai 11k bin1. exp.10x30s No Filter.
dia = 1'; possible Tail 1.25' in PA 240; mag = 13.0 (dia =20")
F.Kugel, Banon (04) France

Francois

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Thu, 24 Sep 2009 07:16:19 +1000
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2008 P1 via GRAS-G5 anim
Thanks Bernhard,

If you follow the link and view the original it is an anim GIF.
The 16bit fits images has been converted to 32bit then despeckled.
Then a square root function followed by a small subtraction to set the low pixels to 1.
Then a log function and the brightness and contrast adjusted.
The best bit has been cropped from the full frames, see attached.

The tail seems to extend beyond 09' on a rough measurement.

Thanks for the feedback , kind regards, Alan
http://cometal.bigblog.com.au/index.do

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed] 

Date:  Wed, 23 Sep 2009 21:22:44 -0000
From:  alan 
Subject:  Re: C/2008 P1 via GRAS-G5 anim
full frame image is here, rgds Alan.

http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/photos/album/2136675078/pic/2053833135/view

From:  Tony 
Subject:  Comet 217P over M42 by Rolando Ligustri  winner of AAPOD

Rolando Ligustri image of Comet 217P Linear over M42 won the Amateur Astronomy Picture of the Day ( AAPOD ) today.

http://astronomy.fm/aapod/2009-09-27_Comet-217P-Linear-crosses-the-belt-of-Orion.html

Congratulations on winning AAPOD with your fantastic image Rolando!

Tony Farkas

Date:  Tue, 29 Sep 2009 21:40:27 +0200
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image of P/2008 O2 (Mc Naught) and two new objects at September, 28 2009
Hello friends of weak comets,

P/2008 O2 (McNaught) by Bernhard Haeusler, B82 Maidbronn 120 minutes
exposure, 2009-09-28 UT 01:52, 12"SCT f-6.532 + ST10XME
19.04 mag, coma: 12", tail: 46" in PA 239°

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2008o2_20090928.htm

GIF Animation:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2008o2_20090928_animation.h
tm

On the image you find two new objects, MAID01 and MAID02.
MAID01 has a typical asteroidical shape, MAID02 may have a small coma?

The image is frozen on stars, comet and new objects.

MAID01 C2009 09 28.07653 00 56 00.90 +16 36 46.5 19.0 R B82
MAID01 C2009 09 28.09095 00 56 00.28 +16 36 42.1 19.4 R B82
MAID01 C2009 09 28.10523 00 55 59.67 +16 36 37.3 19.4 R B82
MAID01 C2009 09 28.11953 00 55 58.98 +16 36 32.6 19.9 R B82

MAID02 C2009 09 28.07653 00 56 10.80 +16 35 02.5 19.7 R B82
MAID02 C2009 09 28.09095 00 56 10.19 +16 35 02.5 20.1 R B82
MAID02 C2009 09 28.11953 00 56 08.60 +16 35 00.6 19.6 R B82

Clear skies
Bernhard B82 Maidbronn
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/ 

Date:  Tue, 29 Sep 2009 23:06:20 -0000
From:  hiro 
Subject:  Re: 217p/Linear approaching M42/43 complex on 21. Sept, 2009
--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, Nico Lonetti wrote:
>
> At 14.08 28/09/2009, you wrote:
> >Hi all, I am new to post here.
> >
> >small version 500 x 333 pixels 156KB:

> >http://tinyurl.com/y9gjnhb

> >
> >http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/
>
> Hi Hiro !
> very intersting images.
> I stretched the histogram image channel
> and I cropped image to the comet.
> You can see your fantasti image here:
>
> http://tinyurl.com/y9gg5po
>
> is there any other tail for this comet ?
> I refer to the north direction...
>
> regards
> Nico, Italy
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>

Hi Nico,

Thank you for the stretching and presentation. I have not noticed the greenish glow in the north, but we should be careful to recognize it as another tail of the comet or not. The comet was drifting and located in one of the most cloud or gas-rich regions in the heavens. We should subtract background cloud or analyze spectrum to come to the strict conclusion, though it looks clearly greenish as the green outer coma of the comet.

hiro 

Date:  Wed, 30 Sep 2009 14:19:41 -0000
From:  hiro 
Subject:  Re: 217p/Linear approaching M42/43 complex on 21. Sept, 2009
> Hi Hiro !
> very intersting images.
> I stretched the histogram image channel
> and I cropped image to the comet.
> You can see your fantasti image here:
>
> http://tinyurl.com/y9gg5po
>
> is there any other tail for this comet ?
> I refer to the north direction...
>
> regards
> Nico, Italy
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>

Hi Nico again,

I reprocessed the image aligning at suspected center of the white dust coma condensation of the comet. The image shows greenish ion coma and another short greenish ion tail toward the north as you say.

link for small version 480 x 320 pixels 100KB: http://tinyurl.com/ybnlgpv

link for full version 5617 x 3749 pixels 13.7MB: http://tinyurl.com/ya7xytg

I should explain some details here.

equipment:
Canon EOS 5D mk2 sp2 by Seo san at ISO 6,400, Takahashi FSQ-106ED refractor, and Reducer QE 0.73x at f3.6 with a specially designed off-axis guider of myself and Starlight Xpress Lodestar Autoguider on Takahashi EM-200 temma 2 Jr. equatorial mount, operated with PHD guiding

exposure: 4 times x 7 minutes
4:32:42-4:54:27 September 21, 2009 in Hawaii-Aleutian time or 14:32:42-14:54:27 September 21, 2009 in UCT

processing with IRIS by Christian Buil:
simply followed "Jim Solomon's Astronomy Cook Book" as always. aligned with coregister4 command firstly, and applied trans2 command at suspected center of the white dust coma condensation of the comet secondly. applied composit command with parameter 3 1 0 to enhance faint part and resulted in saturated brighter parts.

processing with Photoshop CS2 with Astronomy Tools by Noel Carboni
stretched histogram, elevated tone curve as usual, and applied Enhance DSO and Reduce Stars once and Deep Space Noise Reduction once.

regards,
hiro 

Date:  Wed, 30 Sep 2009 16:32:42 +0200
From:  "gvnn64\@libero\.it" 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Re: 217p/Linear approaching M42/43 complex on 21.  Sept,2009
I noticed that this region of the sky is very rich in emission and reflection nebulae (and, indeed, the surroundings of the comet are filled with such beautiful details).

Probably it would be better to blink a couple of images, to be sure that this intriguing "blue tail" actually belongs to the comet.

With kind regards,
Giovanni Sostero 

Date:  Thu, 01 Oct 2009 12:41:35 -0000
From:  hiro 
Subject:  Re:[Comet-Images] Re: 217p/Linear approaching M42/43 complex on 21. Sept, 2009

> Probably it would be better to blink a couple of images, to be sure that this intriguing "blue tail" actually belongs to the comet.
>
> With kind regards,
> Giovanni Sostero
>

Giovanni, Thank you for the advice. I agree with you.

I dug out my old images posted on flickr in the past, and I could find no such greenish cloud in the region as below.

taken with FSQ-106ED with reducer QE 0.73x and EOS 5D mk2 sp2 by Seo san Jan. 2009:
http://tinyurl.com/y98f8h6

taken with EF85mmF1.2L at F3.5 and EOS 5D-AP by IDAS Jan. 2008:
http://tinyurl.com/ydtqrwx

over-cooked image taken with EF135F2.0 at F2.8 and EOS 5D before filter modification Nov. 2006:
http://tinyurl.com/222aqn

They are in "Orion and Eridanus" set on my flickr page:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/

Anyone, please dig out your images of the region. Thank you.

regards,
hiro

Date:  Fri, 09 Oct 2009 01:42:17 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  88P composite, 5-8 October 2009
Composite showing 88P Howell moving past Antares, 5,6 & 8 Oct 09. Missed a night, but that's life! Moving at around 50 arcminutes per day. Lots more 'conjunctions' coming up as 88P moves into a nest of globular clusters in the next few weeks.

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/88P5-8Oct09small.jpg

Cheers -

Rob
http://robsastropics.googlepages.com/comets

Date:  Sat, 10 Oct 2009 20:03:52 -0000
From:  cbellh47 
Subject:  Re: C/2008 P1 (GARRADD) of 9/10
Erik,

Very fine image of C/2008 P1 (GARRADD)

Can you measure the PA and length of the tail in your image.
It looks to be about PA 170?

It appears that the tail has shifted in recent weeks as solar PA has changed.

If using Astrometrica, and have image plate solved, one can measure tail by placing cursor over center of coma, holding the shift key down and dragging mouse, and the program does all the hard work for you, displaying position PA and length conveniently on bottom tab.
Wish there was a way to capture that data though.

Perhaps others know of other programs for making mesurements. I am exploring ImageJ Astronomy plugin.
http://www.astro.physik.uni-goettingen.de/~hessman/ImageJ/Book/index.html

You have a very nice telescope and CCD camera setup.

Charles
H47

Date:  Sun, 11 Oct 2009 13:51:07 +0200
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  RE: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2008 P1 (GARRADD) of 9/10
Hi Charles,

> Very fine image of C/2008 P1 (GARRADD)

thanks !

>Can you measure the PA and length of the tail in your image.
>It looks to be about PA 170?

I'have measured a PA= 169,65 tail is going to the edge of the image. In
this case the length of the tail is > 8'
I made this measurements with Astroart 4,( but attention: AA does not
include any rotating of the image as the camera is not completely correct
aligned.)

>If using Astrometrica, and have image plate solved, one can measure tail by
placing cursor over center of coma,
>holding the shift key down and dragging
> mouse, and the program does all the hard work for you,
>displaying position PA and length conveniently on bottom tab.

I've tried this in Astrometrica, but is see the line and dx, dy an I value
on the bottom, but i can not see the PA or other values.. I miss something ?

>You have a very nice telescope and CCD camera setup.
Thanks, but the image of C/2008 P1 was taken with remote telescope (Tzec
Maun observatory) not in my own observatory.

cheers
Erik

Date:  Fri, 16 Oct 2009 07:47:28 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] imagining comet 217P Linear 15-10-2009
Hello Gustavo,

These are most excellent images of 217P that you are taking.

It would seem appropriate for a report being submitted with some basic coma description and length of tail, PA for the nights you have observed recently.

There is a very dramatic change occurring.

I am patiently waiting for the skies to clear. It has been raining here at H47 for so many weeks now. Hoping to make it out tonight to image the new activity in 217P.

Charles

From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Thank You Group!
Your images are the best. No where else can an account of images be found. It would be nice to have the incoming comets such as C/2009 R1 and C/2009 O2 posted for all to see the progress as they approach. I think perhaps there is another new comet such as these but don't recall the #. This board is not just for the brighter comets but all comet images. I only wish that the weather would allow my imaging to resume but something has the skys cloudy and rainy for months and months and months.

Date:  Sat, 17 Oct 2009 10:01:46 -0700
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Comet 217P/LINEAR October 17, 2009 0849UT
Comet 217P/LINEAR October 17, 2009 0849UT
0.3m Meade 200LX-GPS SCT F/4.7 + AO7+ SBIG ST-8XME + red filter
stack of 3 x 203 sec
Time Stamp: 2009 10 17, 8:49:08 UT
Motion: 0.70"/min in PA 88.3°
Field of View: 32.6' x 21.7'

http://twitpic.com/lutee

Central condensation approximately 90 arc sec diameter elongated PA 297
Coma fans out westward from central condensation PA240 to PA 340 at least 8 arc mins long
Surely in a longer stack of exposure, the fan would be longer.

Hope to try again soon. Its very interesting development. Just a couple of weeks ago, the coma was "tear drop" shaped.

I have been enjoying all the images of 217P and other comets and just wanted to say thanks to all for posting them.
This morning was my first clear morning in weeks. We have had a "monsoon season" coming up from the Gulf for so long now. Everyone's image posts have helped me keep up with what's going on.

Charles Bell H47 Vicksburg

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47

From:  Tony 
Subject:  Comet 217P LINEAR
I here is an image of the 217P LINEAR I took using GRAS NM G3
300 Seconds one shot color

http://astronomy.fm/skylogs/spaw2/uploads/images/heliosphere/217P-1.jpg

in this image you can see a inner coma surrounding the nucleus has brightened up from the recent minor outburst.
http://astronomy.fm/skylogs/spaw2/uploads/images/heliosphere/217P-1s.jpg

Tony

Date:  Mon, 19 Oct 2009 09:54:34 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2008 P1 ?
Very dim (mag. 19.2 nuclear this morning) and diffuse; it is a very difficult object even
via CCD.
I was a bit surprised as well.

Clay

Date:  Tue, 20 Oct 2009 15:39:26 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  P/2009 T2 Oct 19th image

Date:  Tue, 20 Oct 2009 19:47:36 -0000
From:  gustavo 
Subject:  Re: 29P, 217P/linear
ok. for 29P only two exposures 120secs each, bin 2x2, 1.94"/pix.
for 217P was pictures 70 secs, unbinned, 0.97"/pix. 25 exposures.
captured with st8xme with focal reducer 0.67 astroph. telescope is an GPS MEADE 12" not guidded.
clowds was over everywhere, that´s why no guidding was used, normally, is done with AO-8. sky was clowdy, and capture was done with maxim 5 calibrate as well. reduced with astrometrica.
photometry with FOCAS II.
clear filter (no filtered) Seiing not too bad, FWHM2.9

Best regards, gustavo.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "tricks46" wrote:
>

Date:  Tue, 20 Oct 2009 18:27:20 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Comet 217P Oct. 20 from ASO
Image of comet LINEAR 217P on Oct. 20, steady skies with the ASO 0.5 f/4.7m astrograph.
This is a single exposure, 50 sec., no processing.

http://www.arksky.org/asoimg/Com12710296.jpg

Very fine wide tail stretching more than 12 arc minutes.

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  22P/Kopff on Oct 22
22P was only at 18 degrees altitude when I took the image
below, hence the noisy quality..... But as my last image of
22P was 13 years and 3 months ago I thought it was worth
the effort!

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html

Date:  Sat, 24 Oct 2009 16:23:44 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Another Photo Op.
Comets 29P & 81P will come within about 38' on the 26th of this month, 29P at about 14.9 mag and 81P at 13.0. Wider fields should record this fairly good. Good for the record
Mike H. 

Date:  Sat, 24 Oct 2009 19:50:06 +0200
From:  Juan José González Suárez 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Another Photo Op.
Mike,

81P will then be brighter. It was 11.8 in my last visual estimate ( Oct.
16 ).

Clear skies,

J. J. Gonzalez
P.S.: ... waiting for another 29P outburst ...

----------------------------------------

Mike Holloway wrote:

> Comets 29P & 81P will come within about 38' on the 26th of this month, 29P at about 14.9 mag and 81P at 13.0. Wider fields should record this fairly good. Good for the record
> Mike H. 

Date:  Sat, 24 Oct 2009 20:01:30 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  Re: Another Photo Op.
The magnitudes I listed are the predicted values that guide gives for that date. They do not reflect the actual magnitudes the comets are at.
thanks, Mike H.

Date:  Sun, 25 Oct 2009 11:13:10 -0000
From:  Gustavo Muler 
Subject:  image 29P a bit brighter
image 29P a bit brighter this morning, half magn.

http://astrosurf.com/nazaret/images/cometas/29/29-091024-J47.jpg

nuclear activity climb up 0.4 mag. in 10X this morning, multiaperture
observation CCD.

COD J47
OBS G. Muler
CATALOGO: CMC-14 - BANDA: R

10x10 20x20 30x30 40x40 50x50 60x60 RSR FC COD
OBJETO FECHA HORA +/- +/- +/- +/- +/- +/- N FWHM CAT
------------ ---------- -------- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----
---- ---- ---
19-10-2009
29P 20/10/2009 05:42:44 16.37 15.40 14.82 14.41 14.11 13.90 8.2 18.7 J47
29P 20/10/2009 05:42:44* 0.02 0.01 0.02 0.01 0.00 0.01 2 5.2 CMC

24-10-2009
29P 25/10/2009 05:32:09 15.94 15.14 14.71 14.39 14.14 13.95 12.4 19.0
J47
29P 25/10/2009 05:32:09* 0.03 0.05 0.05 0.05 0.05 0.05 4 5.3 CMC

FoCAs II - 13/10/2009
www.astrosurf.com/cometas-obs
es.groups.yahoo.com/group/Cometas_Obs

best regards, gustavo.

Date:  Wed, 04 Nov 2009 13:30:57 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  88P Howell & NGC 6626, 4 Nov 09
Moon's moving back & had a short window tonight. Not a particularly close conjunction though, but thought I'd post as things have been very quiet on Comet_Images recently! Canon 400D, 6 x 60 sec at 200mm.

Small blue star marked in enlargement on annotated version is position of a mag 15 PN (NGC 6620) and a mag 13.0 star. Mag 15 is beyond me, but maybe the star picked up the colour?

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/88PGC4Nov09crop.jpg

Annotated version:
http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/88PGC4Nov09text.jpg

Cheers -

Rob
http://robsastropics.googlepages.com/comets 

Date:  Thu, 05 Nov 2009 22:03:36 -0000
From:  Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Subject:  New file uploaded to Comet-Images

Hello,

This email message is a notification to let you know that
a file has been uploaded to the Files area of the Comet-Images
group.

File : /michael jaeger/169P20091105UT1656s6x25sec_.jpg
Uploaded by : schmidtcamera2500
Description : 169 P 2009 nov 5 M.Jger

You can access this file at the URL:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/files/michael%20jaeger/169P20091105UT1656s6x25sec_.jpg

To learn more about file sharing for your group, please visit:
http://help.yahoo.com/l/us/yahoo/groups/original/general.htmlfiles

Regards,

schmidtcamera2500 

Date:  Tue, 10 Nov 2009 12:12:03 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  Does C/2006 W3 (Christensen) have a tail?
Anyone imaged this comet lately? I imaged C/2006 W3 tonight, my usual 'rough' widefield, and there seems to be indications of a tail. Link to pic is below - the main picture is an actual pixel crop, the insert a 2x resize murdered in Photoshop (apologies). The 'tail' looks more like the comet superimposed on an edge-on galaxy, only there is nothing in that position (RA 19:12.613, Dec -10:51.651, J2000). I checked my planetarium program and the DSS plates.

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/W310Nov0910-30UTcrop.jpg

Canon 400D, 200mm, 5 x 75 sec, ISO 1600, F/5.6. A better image than mine might confirm or reject the existence of a tail. Thanks.

Cheers -

Rob 

Date:  Tue, 10 Nov 2009 15:51:55 -0000
From:  gustavo 
Subject:  Re: Does C/2006 W3 (Christensen) have a tail?
Hello, Rob, I did some shots yesterday, but very windy session.
the fwhm was horrible but the pictures was clear.
this is my process with some filtering, pics are clear filtered, and the comet looks similar to the days before.
they are 10 min. track.

the image
http://astrosurf.com/nazaret/images/cometas/C2006W3/C2006W3-091109-J47.jpg
north up east left.

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "kaufman_rob" wrote:
>
> Anyone imaged this comet lately? I imaged C/2006 W3 tonight, my usual 'rough' widefield, and there seems to be indications of a tail. Link to pic is below - the main picture is an actual pixel crop, the insert a 2x resize murdered in Photoshop (apologies). The 'tail' looks more like the comet superimposed on an edge-on galaxy, only there is nothing in that position (RA 19:12.613, Dec -10:51.651, J2000). I checked my planetarium program and the DSS plates.
>
> http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/W310Nov0910-30UTcrop.jpg
>
> Canon 400D, 200mm, 5 x 75 sec, ISO 1600, F/5.6. A better image than mine might confirm or reject the existence of a tail. Thanks.
>
> Cheers -
>
> Rob
> 

Date:  Tue, 10 Nov 2009 22:14:38 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  Re: Does C/2006 W3 (Christensen) have a tail?
Thanks Gustavo! There's nothing in your shots that I would have picked up, so I suspect it might be an illusion. There is a faint wedge of field stars there, so that could be what is showing. Thought I should post it anyway, in case something was happening.

Cheers -

Rob

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "gustavo" wrote:
>
> Hello, Rob, I did some shots yesterday, but very windy session.
> the fwhm was horrible but the pictures was clear.
> this is my process with some filtering, pics are clear filtered, and the comet looks similar to the days before.
> they are 10 min. track.
>
> the image
> http://astrosurf.com/nazaret/images/cometas/C2006W3/C2006W3-091109-J47.jpg
> north up east left.
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "kaufman_rob" wrote:
> >
> > Anyone imaged this comet lately? I imaged C/2006 W3 tonight, my usual 'rough' widefield, and there seems to be indications of a tail. Link to pic is below - the main picture is an actual pixel crop, the insert a 2x resize murdered in Photoshop (apologies). The 'tail' looks more like the comet superimposed on an edge-on galaxy, only there is nothing in that position (RA 19:12.613, Dec -10:51.651, J2000). I checked my planetarium program and the DSS plates.
> >
> > http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/W310Nov0910-30UTcrop.jpg
> >
> > Canon 400D, 200mm, 5 x 75 sec, ISO 1600, F/5.6. A better image than mine might confirm or reject the existence of a tail. Thanks.
> >
> > Cheers -
> >
> > Rob
> >
> 

Date:  Tue, 10 Nov 2009 16:11:17 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Does C/2006 W3 (Christensen) have a tail?
I am imaging C/2006W3 as I reply. I see nothing to indicate a tail.
This comet has a very low phase angle. If there was one I would assume it would be hidden from our view by the large round coma. But maybe there will be something showing on a stack of images.
Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47

________________________________
From: kaufman_rob
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tue, November 10, 2009 4:14:38 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] Re: Does C/2006 W3 (Christensen) have a tail?

Thanks Gustavo! There's nothing in your shots that I would have picked up, so I suspect it might be an illusion. There is a faint wedge of field stars there, so that could be what is showing. Thought I should post it anyway, in case something was happening.

Cheers -

Rob

it's orbit between the Earth and Mars.

I couldn't find an occultation predicted for that star. (GSC 2375:347)

Date:  Sat, 14 Nov 2009 01:41:44 -0000
From:  gustavo 
Subject:  Re: animation 11-11-2009 of  Herschel Space Observatory (Spacecraft)
Hello Rick and Mike, sorry for the late reply, I get confused, answering the same question in other list.
my apologize.
the asteroid doing the ocultation, is C6755 (17.8) the field center coordinates are _04h12m33,1s_+33d22m11,6s, and they are half an hour of 2x2 binned exposures 1.97"/pix of the ST-8 xme and the 12" meade GPS telescope with a 0.7 reducer.
the guiding, was in charge of the AO-8, my seiing is not as good as we like...
this days are clear, but the weahter was not very polite this year.
wishing you the best, for all your questions Ill be here, tank you so much for watch the animation, gustavo.
Clear Skies. !!!

Date:  Sat, 14 Nov 2009 08:09:59 -0000
From:  gustavo 
Subject:  Re: animation 11-11-2009 of  Herschel Space Observatory (Spacecraft)
Thank you very much for the fast reply.
I put in the Minor Planet and comet Ephemerides service the designation C6755 and the result, was this...

(126755) 2002 DH7

Display all designations for this object / # of variant orbits available = 3

Epoch 2010 Jan. 4.0 TT = JDT 2455200.5 MPC
M 39.41195 (2000.0) P Q
n 0.23261088 Peri. 349.39577 +0.92476421 -0.35462856 T = 2455031.06706 JDT
a 2.6184807 Node 32.46593 +0.36525101 +0.72539186 q = 2.1565157
e 0.1764248 Incl. 14.89916 +0.10678414 +0.58995359
P 4.24 H 15.1 G 0.15 U 1
>From 84 observations at 6 oppositions, 2002-2009, mean residual 0".61.

You requested information on (126755).
Designations that belong: 2002 DH7
Last observed on 2009 Nov. 12. Perturbed ephemeris below based on elements from MPO 160705.

Discovery date : 2002 02 19
Discovery site : Socorro
Discoverer(s) : LINEAR

I think maybe this designation is better explained than the one that appears in astrométrica, again, I am happy than you past x here to see the asteroid (herschel) video !!!

best regards, gustavo.

Date:  Sat, 14 Nov 2009 20:00:00 -0000
From:  Gustavo Muler

>> designation C6755 and the result, was this...
>>
>> (126755) 2002 DH7
>>
>> Display all designations for this object / # of variant orbits
>> available = 3
>>
>> Epoch 2010 Jan. 4.0 TT = JDT 2455200.5 MPC
>> M 39.41195 (2000.0) P Q
>> n 0.23261088 Peri. 349.39577 +0.92476421 -0.35462856 T = 2455031.06706
>> JDT
>> a 2.6184807 Node 32.46593 +0.36525101 +0.72539186 q = 2.1565157
>> e 0.1764248 Incl. 14.89916 +0.10678414 +0.58995359

>> >From 84 observations at 6 oppositions, 2002-2009, mean residual 0".61.

>> Designations that belong: 2002 DH7
>> Last observed on 2009 Nov. 12. Perturbed ephemeris below based on
>> elements from MPO 160705.

>> Discovery date : 2002 02 19
>> Discovery site : Socorro
>> Discoverer(s) : LINEAR

>> appears in astromtrica, again, I am happy than you past x here to see
>> the asteroid (herschel) video !!!

>> > >
>> > > Hello Rick and Mike, sorry for the late reply, I get confused,
>> > > answering the same question in other list.
>> > > my apologize.
>> > > the asteroid doing the ocultation, is C6755 (17.8) the field center
>> > > coordinates are _04h12m33,1s_+33d22m11,6s, and they are half an hour
>> > > of 2x2 binned exposures 1.97"/pix of the ST-8 xme and the 12" meade
>> > > GPS telescope with a 0.7 reducer.
>> > > the guiding, was in charge of the AO-8, my seiing is not as good
>> as we
>> > > like...
>> > > this days are clear, but the weahter was not very polite this year.
>> > > wishing you the best, for all your questions Ill be here, tank you so
>> > > much for watch the animation, gustavo.

Date:  Sat, 14 Nov 2009 22:18:42 -0000
From:  dently2000 
Subject:  Re: animation 11-11-2009 of  Herschel Space Observatory (Spacecraft)
I understand that the Rosetta spacecraft is passing by on its third earth gravity assist and seems well placed at around 02 RA , -18 DEC.
I may look for it tonight..

Rick H. G55

From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: C/2007 Q3 - 2009/11/22
I'm excited too about yet another very active comet, C/2007 Q3, further to the east in the morning sky.

There is 81P, P/2009 Q4 getting more active daily.

217P still looking very nice.

All the good ones are bunched up in the morning sky. Makes the last hour of dark rather busy.

Hi

Thank you for all compliments.

The image i posted thi morning was a first try.

That i have done with the image now.
1. To make the stars a little bit smaller I used Fitswork
2. For DDP i used Astro Arts
3. To remove vignetting i go back to Fitswork

Now I had finished and will post the whole image new.

Date:  Mon, 23 Nov 2009 22:05:06 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Re: Imaging guidelines
Hello Stu,

I see you haven't had an answer yet so I'll pop in. Welcome to the group!

Imaging comets and processing the images is very much like other faint, nebulous targets. However, there is one very important difference: The comets are moving with respect to the fixed star field. This means that if you expose for too long, the comet will be blurred even if the stars are nice and round and not trailed.

So you need to start out by determining the relative motion of the comet. Unless you have SkyMap Pro or SkyTools 3, you need to visit http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/iau/MPEph/MPEph.html
and enter the *exact name* of the comet in the box 1/3 the way down and click on "Get ephemerides/HTML page". The site is very fussy about using the proper comet name.

You will get a return telling you the relative motion of the comet in arc seconds per minute. For example, take a look at Mike's fine image in
http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/message/6194

It would be helpful to all of us if posters to the group would document their images. Data like exposure time, focal ratio and camera would help us. I don't mean this to sound critical, as there is nothing wrong with just posting pretty pictures. But it means that we can't learn much from these fine undocumented images, and for beginners it is hard to break into the comet imaging business.

The "proper" name is C/2007 Q3. Entering that into the box we find that the sky motion is 1.30 arc seconds per minute. You also get the RA/Dec settings for any given day/time. You will need them if you are using a goto scope or setting circles.

For my scope and camera, E-160 and SXV-H9, the image scale (binned 2x2) is 5 arc seconds per pixel. I am willing to allow one pixel blur, so I would expose this comet for a maximum of (5 "/pixel)/(1.30 "/minute) = 3.9 minutes per pixel ~ 4 minute exposures.

I would stack the images manually (I use ImagesPlus) by clicking on the comet head and translating all images so they line up on the head.

To decide what to image, visit
http://cometchasing.skyhound.com/
and
http://www.aerith.net/comet/weekly/current.html .

There you will find the comets ranked in terms of brightness and time to image them.

What kind of equipment are you using? Good luck with your imaging, and drop me an email when you have questions.

Clear skies,

Dennis Persyk
Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
Hampshire, IL
Pier Design http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "sforster12" wrote:
>
> I'm new to this group, and I would greatly appreciate it if one of you could point me to a website/file that gives guidelines for successfully imaging comets.
> Info re: exposure times as well as processing would be greatly appreciated.
>
> Thanks in advance.
>
> STU
>

Date:  Wed, 25 Nov 2009 08:39:30 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Re: Imaging guidelines
Certainly, that's possible, and that's what I do as I still shoot long exposures on film. But in practice you can run into problems with the comet's diffuseness, or the comet could be moving through a field of stars bright enough to "distract" an autoguider. In these cases, I've resorted to manual guiding while watching the image of the comet on a video display.

In other cases, the comet may be moving very slowly and so just autoguiding on a nearby star would be fine.

Dave Kodama

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "sforster12" wrote:
>
> Dennis,
>
> Thanks for the help.
> Can I use a separate guide scope guiding on the comet head?
>
> STU
>
