> > For my scope and camera, E-160 and SXV-H9, the image scale (binned 2x2) is 5 arc seconds per pixel. I am willing to allow one pixel blur, so I would expose this comet for a maximum of (5 "/pixel)/(1.30 "/minute) = 3.9 minutes per pixel ~ 4 minute exposures.
> >
> > I would stack the images manually (I use ImagesPlus) by clicking on the comet head and translating all images so they line up on the head.
> >
> > To decide what to image, visit
> > http://cometchasing.skyhound.com/
> > and
> > http://www.aerith.net/comet/weekly/current.html .
> >
> > There you will find the comets ranked in terms of brightness and time to image them.
> >
> > What kind of equipment are you using? Good luck with your imaging, and drop me an email when you have questions.
> >
> > Clear skies,
> >
> > Dennis Persyk
> > Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> > Hampshire, IL
> > Pier Design http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm
> >
> > --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "sforster12" wrote:
> > >
> > > I'm new to this group, and I would greatly appreciate it if one of you could point me to a website/file that gives guidelines for successfully imaging comets.
> > > Info re: exposure times as well as processing would be greatly appreciated.
> > >
> > > Thanks in advance.
> > >
> > > STU
> > >
> >
> 

Date:  Wed, 25 Nov 2009 12:02:09 -0000
From:  sforster12 
Subject:  Re: Imaging guidelines
This will be a springtime project, as my 120" of snow winter looms ahead.

STU

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "d_kodama" wrote:
>
> Certainly, that's possible, and that's what I do as I still shoot long exposures on film. But in practice you can run into problems with the comet's diffuseness, or the comet could be moving through a field of stars bright enough to "distract" an autoguider. In these cases, I've resorted to manual guiding while watching the image of the comet on a video display.
>
> In other cases, the comet may be moving very slowly and so just autoguiding on a nearby star would be fine.
>
> Dave Kodama
>
> --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "sforster12" wrote:
> >
> > Dennis,
> >
> > Thanks for the help.
> > Can I use a separate guide scope guiding on the comet head?
> >
> > STU
> >
> > --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "dennis_persyk" wrote:
> > >
> > > Hello Stu,
> > >
> > > I see you haven't had an answer yet so I'll pop in. Welcome to the group!
> > >
> > > Imaging comets and processing the images is very much like other faint, nebulous targets. However, there is one very important difference: The comets are moving with respect to the fixed star field. This means that if you expose for too long, the comet will be blurred even if the stars are nice and round and not trailed.
> > >
> > > So you need to start out by determining the relative motion of the comet. Unless you have SkyMap Pro or SkyTools 3, you need to visit http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/iau/MPEph/MPEph.html
> > > and enter the *exact name* of the comet in the box 1/3 the way down and click on "Get ephemerides/HTML page". The site is very fussy about using the proper comet name.
> > >
> > > You will get a return telling you the relative motion of the comet in arc seconds per minute. For example, take a look at Mike's fine image in
> > > http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/Comet-Images/message/6194
> > >
> > > It would be helpful to all of us if posters to the group would document their images. Data like exposure time, focal ratio and camera would help us. I don't mean this to sound critical, as there is nothing wrong with just posting pretty pictures. But it means that we can't learn much from these fine undocumented images, and for beginners it is hard to break into the comet imaging business.
> > >
> > > The "proper" name is C/2007 Q3. Entering that into the box we find that the sky motion is 1.30 arc seconds per minute. You also get the RA/Dec settings for any given day/time. You will need them if you are using a goto scope or setting circles.
> > >
> > > For my scope and camera, E-160 and SXV-H9, the image scale (binned 2x2) is 5 arc seconds per pixel. I am willing to allow one pixel blur, so I would expose this comet for a maximum of (5 "/pixel)/(1.30 "/minute) = 3.9 minutes per pixel ~ 4 minute exposures.
> > >
> > > I would stack the images manually (I use ImagesPlus) by clicking on the comet head and translating all images so they line up on the head.
> > >
> > > To decide what to image, visit
> > > http://cometchasing.skyhound.com/
> > > and
> > > http://www.aerith.net/comet/weekly/current.html .
> > >
> > > There you will find the comets ranked in terms of brightness and time to image them.
> > >
> > > What kind of equipment are you using? Good luck with your imaging, and drop me an email when you have questions.
> > >
> > > Clear skies,
> > >
> > > Dennis Persyk
> > > Igloo (Now Roll-Off) Observatory Home Page http://dpersyk.home.att.net
> > > Hampshire, IL
> > > Pier Design http://home.att.net/~dpersyk/Pier_Design.htm
> > >
> > > --- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "sforster12" wrote:
> > > >
> > > > I'm new to this group, and I would greatly appreciate it if one of you could point me to a website/file that gives guidelines for successfully imaging comets.
> > > > Info re: exposure times as well as processing would be greatly appreciated.
> > > >
> > > > Thanks in advance.
> > > >
> > > > STU
> > > >
> > >
> >
> 

Date:  Wed, 25 Nov 2009 17:55:16 -0000

Date:  Wed, 25 Nov 2009 19:50:54 -0000
From:  dennis_persyk 
Subject:  Re: Imaging guidelines
Hi Stu,

I've never had any luck guiding on a comet head, nor have I heard of any comet imagers using guiding. I use MaximDL for guiding and no matter how I adjust the parameters, the comet eventually runs into a star and the guide camera locks onto the star. If you have a Paramount, you can program in the relative motion so that the mount will follow the comet's trajectory. I don't know of anyone on this list that had done that. I can supposedly do the same with my AP1200GTO, but I've never been able to make it work.

Clear skies,

Dennis

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "sforster12" wrote:
>
> Dennis,
>
> Thanks for the help.
> Can I use a separate guide scope guiding on the comet head?
>
> STU
> 

Date:  Wed, 25 Nov 2009 23:52:40 -0000
From:  d_kodama 
Subject:  Re: Imaging guidelines
Dennis,

I've had pretty good luck with my SBIG STV. And when it can't track reliably, its display screen is a big help for manual tracking.

On the other topic, back in the 1990's a short paper was published on offsetting your polar alignment so the tracking drift matched up with the comet's path. I never used the technique myself, but I thought that was a pretty clever solution.

Dave

--- In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, "dennis_persyk" wrote:
>

>

Date:  Sat, 05 Dec 2009 12:58:31 -0000
From:  kaufman_rob 
Subject:  169P NEAT & 88P Howell, 5 Dec 09
First time I've got anything more than a 'suss' faint dot on 169P after many attempts. But good sky conditions tonight. Despite low elevation near end of twilight I was able to get longer & more subs (aided by a bit of judicious tree pruning), and there appears to be a nice green coma showing.

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/169P5Dec09text.jpg

http://i727.photobucket.com/albums/ww271/Rob_Kau/88P5Nov09text.jpg

Cheers -

Rob
http://robsastropics.googlepages.com/comets

Widefields of these comets in Orion. Surprised that the tiny tail on 217P came out fairly strongly. Tried for 118P in early November but couldn't get a trace - at least I got a faint dot this time! Sky conditions were excellent.

Date:  Wed, 09 Dec 2009 16:43:56 +0000
From:  Ramon Naves 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2007 Q3 (Siding Spring) diferent processing; 217P LINEAR
SAOImage DS9: Astronomical Data Visualization Application
DS9 is a stand-alone application. It requires no installation or support
files. Versions of DS9 currently exist for Solaris, Linux, MacOSX, and
Windows. All versions and platforms support a consistent set of GUI and
functional capabilities.

DS9 supports advanced features such as multiple frame buffers, mosaic
images, tiling, blinking, geometric markers, colormap manipulation,
scaling, arbitrary zoom, rotation, pan, and a variety of coordinate
systems. DS9 also supports FTP and HTTP access.

DOWNLOAD IN http://hea-www.harvard.edu/RD/ds9/

----- Original Message -----
From: Ramon Naves

Sent: Wednesday, December 09, 2009 5:43 PM
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] C/2007 Q3 (Siding Spring) diferent processing; 217P LINEAR

SAOImage DS9: Astronomical Data Visualization Application
DS9 is a stand-alone application. It requires no installation or support
files. Versions of DS9 currently exist for Solaris, Linux, MacOSX, and
Windows. All versions and platforms support a consistent set of GUI and
functional capabilities.

DS9 supports advanced features such as multiple frame buffers, mosaic
images, tiling, blinking, geometric markers, colormap manipulation,
scaling, arbitrary zoom, rotation, pan, and a variety of coordinate
systems. DS9 also supports FTP and HTTP access.

DOWNLOAD IN http://hea-www.harvard.edu/RD/ds9/

Date:  Sat, 12 Dec 2009 18:59:41 -0000
From:  Bernhard 
Subject:  C/2007 Q3 (Siding Spring) at December, 12 2009 UT 11:44
Hi,

image taken remotely at H06, New Mexico.

12.27 mag (10*10 Box), coma: 3'17", tail: 27' in PA 248°
The coma is long stretched, 6' in PA 257.5°

The 10" * 10" box magnitude is increasing around 1 mag since November, 25 2009

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007q3_20091212.htm

Clear skies

Bernd Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn 

Date:  Sat, 12 Dec 2009 20:25:37 +0100

Date:  Tue, 15 Dec 2009 20:33:11 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  image of C/2008 P1 (Garradd) at December, 14 2009
Hello all,

C/2008 P1 (Garradd) by Bernhard Haeusler, B82 Maidbronn, 30 minutes
exposure, 2009-12-14 UT 20:11, 12"SCT f-6.5 + ST10XME
17.47 mag, coma: 8", tail: 27" in PA 133°

Image frozen both on comet and stars.

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2008p1_20091214.htm

Clear skies
Bernhard B82 Maidbronn 

Date:  Wed, 16 Dec 2009 01:16:25 -0000
From:  Tony 
Subject:  Global Rent a Scope holiday gift special
Sounds like a easy way to try out GRAS for free
http://astronomy.fm/gras-holiday.html

Give the gift of Astronomy. A $150 value for free.
Take Your Own Pictures of Deep Sky Objects with Global Rent-A-Scope

Astronomy.FM and Global Rent-a-Scope have teamed up to bring you a free trial account to use on two of their remote-operated observatories. Our special trial account will give you 150 points of free access to GRAS's remote telescopes, G3 (in New Mexico) and G13 (in Australia). Registration does not require a credit card or any commitment from you. At the end of your trial, you will be able to upgrade to a full-use GRAS account that will let you access all of their telescopes.

Date:  Thu, 24 Dec 2009 12:38:04 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  My Christmas Comets of 2009
Merry Christmas and good luck in 2010!

217P/LINEAR and its beautiful coma:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/217p.htm

C/2009 U3 (Hill) with a faint tail of 33" in PA165:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2009u3.htm

C/2008 S3 (Boattini) with a faint tail of 38" in PA93:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2008s3.htm

C/2008 P1 (Garradd) among some faint galaxies:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2008p1.htm

C/2007 N3 (Lulin) has still a tail of 13 arc minutes:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20091218.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3.htm

C/2006 Q1 (McNaught) and its faint coma:
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2006q1.htm

P/2008 J3 (McNaught) is my faintest comet so far: 19.44 mag
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/p2008j3.htm

Saludos and clear skies

Bernhard Haeusler
B82 Maidbronn

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/ 

Date:  Thu, 24 Dec 2009 04:30:00 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] My Christmas Comets of 2009
Very nice Bernhard. I did not realize that Lulin still had a tail at all. I need to go back and look at my most recent images of it. I thought it had faded away. This is a reminder to me to look more closely.

We have so many bright morning comets in the eastern sky before twilight. I have not yest imaged/observed all of them yet.

Best wishes to you and your family for these holidays.

If anyone sees a sleigh flying in the sky tonight, grab a snapshot for the rest of us.

Charles

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47

________________________________

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2008s3.htm

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2008p1.htm

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3_20091218.htm
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2007n3.htm

Date:  Thu, 24 Dec 2009 04:37:47 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] FELICES FIESTAS y próspero 2010 !!!
Thank you Gustavo and everyone here for your friendship and support during this past year. It means so much to me to connect with others doing work in comet astronomy. My observing location is quite remote and far removed from any other astronomers. I learn so much from all of you. I appreciate seeing each and every comet image even though I may not always comment on them.. This is a wonderful yahoo group, always so friendly and encouraging.

Merry Christmas and seasons greetings to all.

Charles

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/

- P2009 Q4 Boattini

Date:  Sat, 26 Dec 2009 07:39:14 -0700
From:  Alan Hale 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comets 29P,81P and C/2007 Q3.
Hello everyone,

>
> Hello,
> New images.
> Comet 29P
> Comet 81P
> Comet C/2007 Q3
> Sigma Teleobjectif 300mm Apo and CCD Audine Kaf 3200 ME
>
> _http://napac.free.fr/_ (http://napac.free.fr/)
> Regards
>

If you look carefully near the northeastern corner (upper left) of the
C/2007 Q3 images, you can also see C/2008 Q3 (Garradd) -- diffuse and vague,
although with an apparent broad faint tail towards the south-southeast.

Sincerely,

Alan

Date:  Sat, 26 Dec 2009 22:41:44 -0000
From:  tricks46 
Subject:  10P
Anyone put this one on the chip this time around? Shows to be a nice show next July with a current guide estimated magnitude of 16.4 rising a couple of hours before morning light.
Mike H. 

Date:  Sat, 26 Dec 2009 15:00:30 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 10P
That's what Seiichi Yoshida has on his web site. His light curve projects brightening in the coming weeks. Thanks for the heads up. Will try to observe it when it gets brighter than mag 18. The Minor Planet Center shows last observed in April 2009 at mag 19+.

http://www.aerith.net/comet/catalog/0010P/2010.html

Twitter: http://twitter.com/cbellh47
Flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/cbellh47/
Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/cbellh47

Date:  Wed, 30 Dec 2009 15:00:49 +0100
From:  Bernd Häusler 
Subject:  comets C/2008 P1 (Garradd) and C/2009 Y2 (Kowalski) at December 26, 2009
Hi comet photographers,

two faint comets snaped at December 26:
C/2008 P1 (Garradd) with a nice tail, but very dense coma.
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2008p1.htm

C/2009 Y2 (Kowalski) is an extreme faint new comet, showing neither coma nor
tail on my images.
http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/c2009y2.htm

Clear skies and all the best for 2010

Bernhard Haeusler
MPC B82 Maidbronn

http://www.amication.de/Bernhards_Comet_Project/
